title: coronavirus vodafone o2 talktalk down outage data
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Mass outages come as containment measures see&nbspmore people go onlineMajor&nbspphone networks and internet providers in the UK are suffering increased outages and down time due to a huge strain on their infrastructure caused by the Covid-19 coronavirus pandemic.Vodafone said it is experiencing a 30 per cent rise in internet use, while TalkTalk&nbspsaid traffic has risen 20 per cent since Monday.The increased demand comes as more people are working remotely and self isolating in an effort to prevent the spread of the deadly virus.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesA mass outage earlier this week saw EE, O2, Three and Vodafone all face issues, with customers complaining that they were unable to call, message or get online.At a time when the country needs connectivity most, it is important we work together rather than point fingers, an O2 spokesperson told&nbspThe Independent.The dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and the common cold and flu?Can face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The UK government's four stages of fighting coronavirus explainedWhat are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?Similar outages have afflicted remote working tools like Microsoft Teams, following a huge influx of new users.Containment measures in the UK are expected to become more strict over the coming days, with reports suggesting the country will be placed on a&nbsplockdown&nbspsimilar to that of France or Italy. There have been more than 2,600 confirmed cases of the coronavirus in the UK, resulting in 108 deaths.Schools across England will close from Friday, adding further strain to network infrastructure as children access educational materials online.The closures will also likely mean an increase in other online activities, like playing video games or watching films and TV shows through streaming sites.Created with Sketch.Before and after photos show impact of coronavirus around the world Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, BethlehemIn an effort to maintain its network and cope with increased demand, Vodafone announced a five-point plan to ensure that critical services are not affected.Parts of the plan include prioritising mission critical communications and increasing network capacity for hospitals and government functions.Vodafone can play a critical role in supporting society during this unprecedented time and that is why we are announcing our five-point plan, said Vodafone CEO Nick Read.Through our networks, and our dedicated team, we will strive to ensure that people stay connected to their family and friends, businesses can continue to run using remote working, our health services get all the support we can deliver and students are able to continue their education virtually.One way of coping with increased demand is to force Netflix and other online streaming services to lower the resolution of content, according to European Union commissioner Thierry Breton.To secure internet access for all, let's switch to standard definition when HD is not necessary, he tweeted on Wednesday.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus pubs social distancing young people self isolate
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Warning to young people across the UK comes as chief medical officer says it is now unlikely the Covid-19 virus will ever go awayYoung people across Britain have been told to stop mixing in pubs and bars by the government’s top science adviser as the country was warned it was likely the coronavirus will never go away.At a briefing for health journalists in central London today Sir Patrick Vallance, the UK’s chief scientific adviser urged youngsters to stop socialising.Sir Patrick said it was important young people followed the advice on social distancing.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe mixing in pubs and restaurants needs to stop and it needs to stop among young people as well as older,'' he said.His warning came amid concern young people were dismissive of the disease believing wrongly that it only affected elderly people.Chief medical officer Professor Chris Whitty added it was now likely the coronavirus was here to stay.He said: “It is our judgement, and it is my judgement certainly, if you look around the world, the idea that we're going to put this virus back to going away and completely whilst not theoretically impossible, seems so improbable that based on scientific theory that is something we are trying to do. Seems to me a mistake.”He said: “However much we would like there to be a vaccine riding to the rescue in six months time. Currently, we think that's improbable. So now we've got to work on a different theoretical framework for actually managing this epidemic.”Professor Whitty said normal public health responses to a disease, like those used to isolate ebola in West Africa were no longer likely to be effective against what was now a global pandemic virus.He said those tools such as containing and isolating infected people might work for some countries but the stage of the epidemic in the UK had gone beyond that position.He added that even if the UK could reduce infections it was almost inevitable the virus would return as it was a truly global infection.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus update live cases uk news symptoms tips map
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Follow the latest updates on the pandemicEmergency legislation to slow the spread of the coronavirus outbreak is set to be published in parliament after Boris Johnson announced the closure of schools.&nbspThe Emergency Coronavirus Bill, tabled by the health secretary, Matt Hancock, will also include plans to hand police powers to arrest and isolate people to protect public health.Meanwhile, the Army is preparing to help out in the crisis as part of a “Covid support force” and Londoners faced the prospect of greater restrictions, with up to 40 Tube stations closed on Thursday and a reduced rail service from Friday. Several supermarkets are limiting the number of products customers can buy in stores to meet the demand amid the Covid-19 outbreak.Elsewhere, Donald Trump has crowned himself a “wartime president” fighting an invisible enemy, and has invoked rarely used emergency powers to marshal critical medical supplies against the pandemic. Mr Trump will also use&nbsphis authority under the 70-year-old Defense Production Act to give the government more power to steer production by private companies and try to overcome a shortage in masks, ventilators and other supplies. The number of people infected worldwide has surpassed the 200,000 mark, according to the Johns Hopkins University, as deaths topped 8,700 – though the number of people considered recovered reached over 83,000.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesFollow the latest updatesEmergency legislation to be published in parliamentSchools to close, Army preparing to help out and police handed powers to arrest and isolateUp to 40 Tube stations to close across LondonSupermarkets limit number of products customers can buyUS Navy veteran released from prison in IranMichael White, 47, a US Navy veteran, has been released on medical furlough in Iran, as the country battles to contain the spread of the deadly coronavirus,&nbspBel Trew&nbspreports.Mr White, who was arrested 2018 for an unspecified crime, is serving a 13-year sentence.His was released on humanitarian grounds on the condition he stayed in Iran, the State Department said on Thursday adding that he has been “wrongfully detained”.Mr White is now in the custody of the Swiss embassy and will undergo medical testing and evaluation, the statement added.The former serviceman was arrested in July 2018 while visiting his Iranian girlfriend, The New York Times reported. The Iranian authorities have never explained why he is being held.The US urged the Iranian government to immediately release on humanitarian grounds other US citizens behind bars including Morad Tahbaz, Baquer Namazi, and Siamak Namazi.&nbsp“We also ask the regime to honour the commitment it made to work with the United States for the return of Robert Levinson,” who disappeared in 2007, the State Department communique read.Iran has temporarily freed about 85,000 people from jail, including political prisoners, in response to the coronavirus epidemic.Hardware shops should remain open, Green Party leader saysGreen Party leader Eamon Ryan called for hardware shops to remain open during the Covid-19 outbreak.How we maintain the mental health of our people is important and I recited an example the other day. How about we keep our hardware shops open? I know that is not the most important thing but if we keep our hardware shops open and if we have to work at home or be at home for a period we can get paint from the hardware shop.Or let's get every south-facing windowsill in this country. Let's plant our seeds in the next week so that if there is a supply crisis in food in a few months' time and when this gets really hard, we will have our salads ready to go.Suspected shoplifter arrested after coughing on staff and claiming to be infectedA man suspected of shoplifting has been arrested after coughing on store staff and claiming to be infected with Covid-19.West Midlands Police said a 57-year-old man was held on suspicion of theft and assault in Dudley on Thursday afternoon.Officers were called to Dudley High Street after several people reported a man coughing on shop staff who had suspected him of stealing.In a statement, a force spokesman said: The man, who is from Dudley and has suspected mental health issues, has been taken into custody and will be questioned in due course.Those affected have been given appropriate advice and referred to the non-emergency NHS helpline for further support and guidance.Additional ventilators orderedSome 40 additional mechanical ventilators (30 adult units and 10 paediatric units) have been ordered, which will bring the total available in Northern Ireland to 179 by the end of March.Plans are in place to rapidly increase the number of critical care beds.Key staff will be redeployed to coronavirus duties as non-urgent appointments and procedures are halted.Surgery for the treatment of cancer and other urgent procedures will continue.All health trusts will ensure patients who are medically well are safely and rapidly discharged from hospital, with appropriate care arrangements, to keep beds available for any increase in admissions.Routine GP work will be adjusted or suspended in the first number of weeks of the epidemic.Community pharmacies will endeavour to deliver an increased proportion of prescriptions, avoiding the need for people to travel to a community pharmacy.Services will be prioritised for those most in need, the vulnerable and those at risk of harm.This will include children's and young people, older people, mental health and learning disability services.England death toll increases by 29The UK death toll has increased&nbspto 128, NHS England has announced.A further 29 people, who tested positive for the Coronavirus (COVID-19) have died, NHS England said.Patients were aged between 47 and 96 years old and had underlying health conditions.Brits most pessimistic about economy sine 2008 financial crisisPeople in Britain are at their most pessimistic about the outlook for the economy since the 2008 financial crisis because of the coronavirus pandemic, polling firm Ipsos MORI said.A poll of showed 69 per cent&nbspof respondents thought the economy would get worse in the next 12 months, sharply up from 42 per cent&nbspin February.Around half the public felt the government was handling the crisis well, although half were wanting more to be done, Gideon Skinner, head of political research at Ipsos MORI, said.The poll of 1,003 people was conducted between 13 March and 16 March, before some of the most recent emergency measures were announced.Dutch confirm 409 new cases and 18 new deathsThe number of confirmed cases of coronavirus in the Netherlands has risen by 409 to a total of 2,460, Dutch health authorities said in their daily update, with 18 new deaths.The total death toll in the Netherlands now stands at 76, with victims ranging from 63 years to 95 years old.A total of 489 patients were or have been hospitalized, the Netherlands' National Institute for Health (RIVM) said in a statement.Logistical problem in distributing personal protective equipmentChris Hopson, chief executive of NHS providers, said there was a logistical problem in distributing personal protective equipment to healthcare workers, but not a shortage, after a doctor likened the lack to soldiers inside Snatch Land Rovers in the Iraq war.He told BBC Radio 4's World At One programme: We have obviously been talking to national NHS leaders and what they say to us is there are sufficient national stocks of personal protection equipment but there is currently a problem in terms of the logistical distribution of them.What's happened is that because of the sudden and understandable spike in demand it is taking a bit of time for the logistical distribution to catch up but the bit that they are saying to us is there are sufficient national stocks, the issue is actually ensuring that those stocks reach the frontline in the right numbers, in the right places, at the right time.His comments came after Dr Paul Evans, a GP in Gateshead, told the programme that frontline staff did not have PPE that inspires the confidence of the staff who would have to use it when seeing patients potentially affected by coronavirus 19.Dr Evans said: I would suggest that asking health professionals to see patients with a potentially lethal aerosol or airborne transmitted illness without adequate PPE draws an uncomfortable parallel with a decade or so ago sending soldiers to Afghanistan and Iraq in Snatch Land Rovers that were referred to by the troops at the time as mobile coffins.People can die 'directly and indirectly,' chief medical officer saysChief medical officer for England Professor Chris Whitty said people can die directly and indirectly during an epidemic.He said: People die in these epidemics... for two reasons.They die directly of the infection, unavoidably, best medical care, sadly this is still going to happen for some people.But also they can die because the health service they are in is overwhelmed and therefore there's an indirect death because there's a difference between what could happen with health and what we were able to provide in this situation.On reducing the peak of the infection, he added: It has an additional advantage, if you let an epidemic run its full course you get what's called overshoot where more people get infected than you would need if it were to run at a lower peak.Actually by lowering the peak you reduce the overall number of people who will get the infection.M&ampS announces special shopping hoursMarks and Spencer has followed in the footsteps of other supermarkets and announced special shopping hours for NHS and emergency workers, as well as older and vulnerable customers.The first hour of trading tomorrow will be set aside for vulnerable customers, and from next week will happen every Monday and Thursday.Meanwhile, the first hour on Tuesdays and Fridays have been set aside for NHS staff and emergency workers.This does not include franchise stores in petrol and railway stations.Writing on Twitter, the company said: We ask our other customers to respect this request, as it's the kindness and support we show each other that will get us through this.Daytime TV sees viewing spikeDaytime TV shows - as well as news - have seen a spike in viewing.ITV Daytime, including shows such as Loose Women and This Morning, reached a six-year high, the broadcaster said.The BBC news bulletin at 6pm had an audience of 8.7 million, its highest figure since Christmas Day 2008.ITV said its lunchtime news bulletin had its biggest audience since New Year's Day 2014, with 1.6 million viewers.Please allow a moment for the blog to loadNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Department for Transport begin public consultation to change law decades after ban introducedThe forbidden art of using&nbspplanes to write&nbspmessages in the skies&nbspabove the UK&nbspis set to make a comeback for the first time in 60&nbspyears.Skywriting and skytyping were&nbspbanned by the government in&nbsp1960 because of concerns over safety and the potential spread of political propaganda.However officials are now planning to change the&nbsplaw to allow the creation of mid-air advertising slogans, birthday greetings and marriage proposals.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe Department for Transport&nbsp(DfT) estimates that skytyping – which involves emitting puffs of smoke to create a line of text – could raise £4m in tax revenue in five years.It would also revitalise the aviation and advertising industries and expand the market for&nbspexpert British skywriting pilots who can only work abroad. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Former work and pension secretary says his Universal Credit scheme would be a better way of dealing with diseaseIain Duncan Smith has rejected suggestions that workers should be given a universal basic income during the coronavirus pandemic, arguing that it would be a disincentive to work.The former work and pensions secretary said the proposal, floated by Labour leadership candidate Rebecca Long-Bailey on Wednesday, was also unaffordable.Under the proposed policy, people would receive a universal flat payment to help cover their living costs during the pandemic. Ms Long Bailey's proposal is for the rate to be set at the living wage.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut Sir Iain, said his think-tank the Centre for Social Justice had ran the numbers and found that the cost would amount to an astronomic amount of money - with a basic payment costing the Treasury around £260 billion a year.He suggested that the delayed Universal Credit scheme, his main legacy at the DWP, would be a better alternative and was designed with just such critical moments in mind.Rebecca Long-Bailey calls for universal basic income during pandemicOne proposal being pushed around at the moment is the redundant idea of a Universal Basic Income, Sir Iain&nbspwrote in an article for the  newspaper.Let me say now, it’s unaffordable, impractical, produces massive disincentives for people to work and most importantly won’t make any difference to poverty in this country.&nbspAnd even if that weren’t enough, this would not be the moment for such a massive upheaval of our welfare system.Sir Iain said the taper rate of his own Universal Credit system should instead be lowered to pay more money to people who lose hours due to the pandemic and put a floor underneath employees as government steps in and takes the strain.Writing in  on Wednesday, the Shadow Business Secretary Ms Long-Bailey called for a fixed payment made to all, providing everyone with a basic minimum income of at least the real living wage, for the duration of the coronavirus pandemic.Created with Sketch.Coronavirus fears lead to empty streets and shelves across UK Show all title: coronavirus vaccine covid 19 trials seattle cure immunity us
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Thirty-five companies said to be looking for treatmentWhen Jennifer Haller saw a friend’s Facebook post requesting volunteers for the trial of a potential coronavirus vaccine, she barely paused.&nbspThe same day she filled out the online form asking questions about her medical health. The following morning&nbspshe received a phone call asking more questions&nbspand requesting she give a blood sample for screening. She checked out.At 8am on Monday the 43-year-old, who has two teenage children, Ellie and Hayden, was the first of 45 volunteers from the Seattle area to be injected in the upper left arm with a drug its developers believe could help beat Covid-19. Nothing is certain, the outcomes are unknown. But Haller and the other volunteers are happy to be playing their part.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“I think we all feel so helpless,” Haller tells The Independent, when asked why she was so willing to take part. “And this was a great opportunity to try and make a difference. I’m so thankful that I have this opportunity. It’s a privilege to be healthy, and to have a job that is flexible enough to let me do this.”&nbspHaller is a small but crucial part of a global effort to confront the coronavirus, which has upended lives, threatened economic ruin, confined people to their homes&nbspand, perhaps, allowed us to take stock of what in our lives we ought most to value.Created with Sketch.Before and after photos show impact of coronavirus around the world Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, BethlehemAs of Thursday, global infections had topped 218,000 and the death toll raced past 9,000. Across the world, stock markets are in free-fall&nbspand governments are struggling to enforce measures to “flatten the curve”.A light at the end of what could be a very long tunnel would be a vaccine to effectively treat the disease and allow life to try to&nbspreturn to normal. Experts point out the disease has disrupted and devastated life in ways we are struggling to conceive. But so&nbspdid diseases such as measles, polio, smallpox and tuberculosis.Reports suggest as many as 35 pharmaceutical firms, some aided by grants from government or philanthropists, are involved in the hunt for a vaccine for Covid-19. These firms are part of a massive industry and a vaccine market said to be worth $35bn&nbsp(£30bn).The trial in which&nbspHaller is taking part involves a drug developed by Moderna, a biotechnology firm based in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Another trial, involving a drug developed by Pennsylvania-based Inovio Pharmaceuticals, could start next month. A German firm, CureVac, is said to be working on a potential vaccine, one the Trump administration reportedly tried to buy.“They are all racing against the disease, rather than against each other,” says John Tregoning, an expert in infectious diseases at Imperial College London.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“The more irons there are in the fire, the greater the chance of coming up with something. Also, it will help with the ability to produce as many as 9&nbspbillion vaccines.”The trial under way in Seattle, backed by the national institutes of health (NIH) and Kaiser Permanente Washington Research Institute, involves a drug called&nbsp​mRNA-1273.“Over the past few years, we have demonstrated its potential in vaccines across more than 1,000 subjects in our clinical trials,” Moderna says. “This includes successful early-stage (Phase 1) clinical trials against five other respiratory viruses (two pandemic influenza strains, RSV, hMPV and PIV3). Over the last four years, we have started nine clinical trials for mRNA vaccines.“We had previously collaborated with the NIH on a vaccine for MERS-CoV, which is a different type of coronavirus than the current pandemic. While the programme was only at the research stage, it provided significant insights.”Experts point out one of the reasons there is much excitement about what is happening in Seattle&nbspis that, unlike many previous vaccines,&nbspmRNA-1273 does not involve a sample of the actual virus. Rather, with input from Chinese authorities about the genetic sequence of the coronavirus first detected in the city of Wuhan, it makes use of messenger RNA molecules.&nbspThese instruct the body to produce its own immune response to fight again the coronavirus. It means those taking part in trials are not exposed to the virus&nbspand could theoretically speed up the process of identifying a vaccine.“We don’t know whether this vaccine will induce an immune response or whether it will be safe. That’s why we’re doing a trial. It’s not at the stage where it would be possible or prudent to give it to the general population.”In what critics have said is a succession of factual errors about the coronavirus and its threat to the US and the world, Donald Trump told reporters a vaccine could be produced within “weeks”.One of his top health officials, Anthony Fauci, director of the national institute of allergy and infectious diseases, was soon obliged to pour cold water on the president’s claims.“The whole process is going to take a year, year-and-a-half at least,” he said. “I don’t want to overpromise.”Tregoning, of Imperial College London, says there is a very strict protocol that is followed with developing potential vaccines, despite, or perhaps because of, the pressure to move too quickly. As such, any drug can only be made available after approval of a national licensing body or the World Health Organisation.&nbsp“What we don’t want is something making the situation worse,” he says.Coronavirus: What is herd immunity and is it a possibility?Israeli spyware firm builds software to map Covid-19 patient movementInfluencer Arielle Charnas tells followers she has coronavirus Haller, who works for a tech start-up and who says her children think it’s “cool” she is taking part, has been asked to write a daily journal and speaks on the phone with one of the Kaiser team most days.Every week&nbspshe needs to give a blood sample, and in a month she will receive the second dose of the vaccine. The 45 volunteers, all aged 18 to 55, have been split into three groups, with different strengths given to each.&nbspThe monitoring will last a year&nbspbut Moderna says safety data will be available a few weeks after the injections are given.&nbspA Moderna official told the New York Times&nbspthat if the drug appears safe it will ask the Food and Drug Administration&nbspfor permission to move ahead to the next phase of testing to assess its effectiveness. That would involve a larger number of volunteers.For now, Haller is going about her life, hoping her efforts can help not just her fellow Americans&nbspbut people around the world.“It’s wild,” she says. “It’s incomprehensible to me right now&nbspbut I am so thankful to be part of it.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus bernie sanders us universal income 2020 election
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Candidate floats universal basic income proposal as concept gathers traction across political spectrumBernie Sanders has outlined an ambitious “emergency response” to fight the spread of coronavirus and its impact on the US – including a radical proposal to give every American $2,000 (£1,700) a month.In an address streamed live on Periscope, Mr Sanders discussed an ambitious series of measures to help Americans withstand the economic havoc wrought by the coronavirus outbreak, which is expected to devastate the job market and put many small businesses in danger of collapse.Among his many prescriptions are expanded unemployment insurance, massive efforts to feed those who need food assistance, a moratorium on evictions, and a waiver on all student loan payments for the duration of the emergency. But it is the universal $2,000 payment that sticks out as truly radical.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“Bottom line here: workers need to continue to get a paycheck, even when their businesses are shut down,” said Mr Sanders.“Further, we need to provide a direct emergency $2,000 cash payment to every household in America every month for the duration of the crisis to provide them with the assistance they need to pay their bills and take care of their families.”How to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?Mr Sanders, who is losing the fight for the Democratic nomination, then conceded that his plan is not likely to go anywhere.“Now, we’re throwing out a lot of ideas. And when you deal with the United States Congress, you don’t get everything that you want. There will be a picking and a choosing here and there.“But I think it’s important for us tonight to discuss the various options that they have, and one of those options is to make sure that people at least get a $2,000 a month cheque to take care of their basic needs.”Created with Sketch.Before and after photos show impact of coronavirus around the world Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, BethlehemThe proposal for what would essentially amount to a universal basic income has helped direct attention back to Mr Sanders’s onetime fellow presidential candidate Andrew Yang, who dropped out of the race after the New Hampshire primary.&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailMr Yang’s signature policy was to roll out a universal basic income called the “Freedom Dividend”. Once dismissed as a technocrat fantasy, it is now surfacing in proposals from people on all sides, from Mr Sanders to progressive congresswoman Ilhan Omar to former Trump administration press secretary Antonio Scaramucci.In his full written proposal, Mr Sanders expands on how the payments would work, calling for an effort involving “the IRS, the Social Security Administration, the Treasury Department, credit unions, community banks and other financial institutions”.He also acknowledges that not all Americans need the money, and carves out a different role for them: “For those who will not need their payments, we will partner with organisations to take donations from patriotic families who can contribute their payments to fighting the coronavirus pandemic.”Mr Sanders has fallen well behind Joe Biden in the race for the Democratic nomination, most recently losing primaries in Arizona, Florida and Illinois by wide margins. title: coronavirus new york us cases positive tests update
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Mayor&nbspBill de Blasio called for US military assistance&nbspas the number of confirmed cases in New York CIty doubled overnightThe number of confirmed cases of coronavirus in New York City more than doubled overnight on Wednesday, with 1,871 people testing positive for the disease.&nbspThere were 948 new coronavirus cases on Wednesday. New York City Mayor, Bill de Blasio, had announced on Tuesday that the total number of confirmed cases stood at 923. It marks the largest one-day increase of the Covid-19 disease in New York.&nbspOne week ago, the total number of coronavirus cases in New York state was 216, and 11 in the week before that. The state’s governor, Andrew Cuomo, announced on Wednesday morning that there were now 2,382 confirmed coronavirus cases in New York state, of which 1,871 were in New York City.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThere have been at least 20 people across New York state who have died from the virus.In an interview with CNN last night, New York City Mayor de Blasio expressed his concern that the rate of increase in coronavirus cases would continue to rise.&nbspNYC health officials believe that there are enough medical supplies for the “immediate future” but not to meet increasing demands.“Yesterday we saw a jump of a hundred cases, today we saw a jump of hundreds of cases,” said Mayor de Blasio. &nbsp“You are talking about a massive surge in demand. We have been appealing constantly to the federal government to start a supply system that will actually help our hospitals survive an unprecedented surge in cases. This is the problem.”The Mayor added: “Hospitals are going to have massive new demands, and things like surgical masks – you just burn through those in a normal day let alone in an emergency”.How to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?“President Trump has to mobilise the United States military to fully act in the coronavirus situation.”Asked by CNN news anchor Andrew Cooper if he wanted to see the United States military setting up hospitals in the streets of New York City, Mayor de Blasio said “I do’’.&nbsp“I am talking about the United States military going where they can save the most lives of Americans, and that’s places like New York, Seattle and California and soon that’s going to be a lot of other places”&nbspWith the number of cases across the US set to continue rising, Mayor De Blasio said Americans should look to California and its attempts at slowing the disease with minimal activity and an end to all non-essential work.&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: china coronavirus wuhan update cases hubei covid 19
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Across Asia, attention turns from preventing local infections to stopping international travellers bringing new cases inChinese officials say they have “seen the dawn” of an end to the coronavirus epidemic, after the country reported zero new cases of local infection for the first time since the outbreak began.Figures for Wednesday showed there were no new cases at all in Wuhan or the wider Hubei province, where the virus now known as Covid-19 is believed to have first transmitted among humans.Authorities warned the risk was still not over, though, as 34 cases – all imported from abroad – were reported in other provinces. They included 21 in Beijing and nine in the southern manufacturing hub of Guangdong.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThere were also eight new deaths on Wednesday, according to the National Health Commission. bringing the country to a total of 80,928 cases and 3,245 deaths.Nonetheless, the lack of new local transmissions in Hubei was hailed as a major landmark in the global fight to contain the disease.How to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?“Today we have seen the dawn after so many days of hard effort,” said Jiao Yahui, a senior inspector at the National Health Commission.Li Yang, an official from Hubei’s Centre for Disease Control and Prevention, told a news conference that the threat of Covid-19 had not been eliminated and infection risk still persists, at both community and clinic levels.Wuhan has been under a strict lockdown since January, and remains cut off with only those with special permission allowed to travel in or out.Officials are moving to loosen travel restrictions, but only inside the surrounding province of Hubei where most checkpoints will be taken down.The lockdown in Wuhan will be lifted only if no additional cases are reported for two consecutive weeks, something which could happen as early as next month, Li Lanjuan, a member of the Chinese Academy of Engineering, told local media.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailBut attention in China and across Asia is increasingly turning from stopping local spread to preventing new cases from arriving abroad. China is even assisting governments in Europe – sending medical supplies to France, for example, returning a favour done by Paris a few weeks ago.Alarmed by the 21 new cases arriving in Beijing – a record number – the Chinese aviation authority said it had appointed 12 airport companies to assist in erting international arrivals away from the capital.A state media report on the announcement did not elaborate which cities the traffic would be erted to, but the measure is designed to help with effective screening of passengers and isolation of infected travellers.Created with Sketch.Before and after photos show impact of coronavirus around the world Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, BethlehemIn Japan, there were only three new infection cases on Wednesday, and the governor of the worst-hit Hokkaido province announced the end of a state of emergency. “From the 20th we move to a new stage to overcome the crisis,” Naomichi Suzuki told reporters.While mass gatherings are still effectively banned, an expert panel on the virus outbreak was expected to recommend that some schools be reopened and sporting events resumed.Koji Wada, a member of the panel, told Reuters that “there are some areas where almost all the patients have been identified in the past two weeks ... So in those areas, it’s OK to reopen schools, even now.”Singapore reported 47 new cases on Wednesday, but of those 33 were imported – including 30 returning Singapore residents, taking the country’s total to 313.The imported cases had travelled to European countries including the UK, Turkey, France, Germany, Austria, Croatia and Switzerland, as well as India, Indonesia, the Philippines and the US.South Korea, which has been widely praised for its handling of the outbreak through aggressive testing measures, has reduced its rate of new infections to double digits in recent days. On Wednesday, that jumped to 152 new cases. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'They held the&nbspKhatme&nbspShifa&nbspprayers after dawn to free the country from the coronavirus,' say policeAround 10,000 Muslim worshippers gathered in a prayer session in Bangladesh after the country reported its first death related to coronavirus to pray “healing verses” from the Quran to protect the country from the pandemic.Local police said the mass gathering took place in an open field in the town of Raipur, southern Bangladesh, on Wednesday.Police chief Tota Miah told news agency AFP: “They held the Khatme Shifa prayers after dawn to free the country from the coronavirus.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOrganisers of the gathering, who police say did not secure permission to hold it, claimed there were 25,000 attendees.Images of the prayer session shared on social media were widely criticised, with people calling the gathering “unbelievable”.The dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and the common cold and flu?Can face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The UK government's four stages of fighting coronavirus explainedWhat are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?The Bangladeshi government have closed down schools and advised the public to avoid gatherings of more than ten people to curb the spread of coronavirus, which has infected 14 people in the south Asian nation.But with many ignoring the warnings and heading to tourism sites and mass gatherings instead, authorities are considering imposing a lockdown.Obaidul Quader, a senior leader from ruling party Awami League, told reporters: “If necessary, Bangladesh will be shut down. It’ll be enforced where necessary.“People must be saved first. We’ll do everything for that.”In Indonesia, a mosque in Jakarta is still planning to hold Friday mass prayers despite warnings from the government to restrict public gatherings.A spokesman for the Istiqlal Mosque told local news agency Antara: “The mosque’s grand imam Nasaruddin&nbspUmar has instructed that the Friday mass prayer for this week will be held as usual following the Indonesian Ulama Council’s (MUI) decision.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus spread afghanistan taliban health workers world health organisation
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘The Islamic Emirate assures all international health organisations&nbspof its readiness to cooperate and coordinate with them in combating the coronavirus,’ says group’s spokesmanScared by the prospect a coronavirus epidemic in parts of Afghanistan under their control, the Taliban have pledged their readiness to work with healthcare workers instead of killing them, as they have been accused of in the past.Back in September, the Taliban lifted a ban on the World Health Organisation&nbsp(WHO) and Red Cross from operating in militant-held territory, having warned them off in April because of suspicions over polio vaccination campaigns.Whatever reservations the militants held over eradicating that crippling disease, they have clearly grasped the dangers posed by coronavirus pandemic sweeping the rest of the world.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“The Islamic Emirate via its Health Commission assures all international health organisations and WHO of its readiness to cooperate and coordinate with them in combating the coronavirus,” said Suhail Shaheen, the Taliban’s spokesman, on Twitter, using the term the group uses to describe itself.In a report in December, the WHO refrained from naming the Taliban or any other militant group as it counted the human and social cost of targeted attacks on healthcare during 2019.How to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?At least 51 healthcare workers, patients and supportive staff were killed and 142 others wounded. As a result of the attacks 192 health facilities were closed, of which only 34 were reopened. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attacks that Afghan authorities have blamed on their fighters.Afghanistan currently has 22 confirmed coronavirus cases, with concerns growing particularly over the danger of infections among the thousands of Afghans crossing the border with Iran: one of the worst-affected nations.The country’s woefully inadequate health system would undoubtedly be overwhelmed if the virus were to take hold. Moreover, after 18 years of war the government only controls about half of the country.The rest is either controlled or contested by the insurgents, who have agreed a peace deal with the United States but have yet to open talks with the government.Communities in ethnic Pashtun rural areas where the Taliban hold sway could suffer from the loss of access to health support in their villages as a result of past militant action.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailAccess can be even worse for women in these communities due to conservative Pashtun attitudes on gender.Rahila, a 31-year-old woman living in Takhar province, said that in her village in a Taliban-controlled area there was a health clinic with only male doctors.“When we get sick we are not allowed to go to a doctor, instead our husbands bring medicine for us,” Rahila&nbspsaid, asking not to publish her full name over safety concerns. “Who will test the women?”She added: “What if a woman has a coronavirus? Everyone in our village will be affected. If magic happens and helps the Taliban, then the Taliban can prevent coronavirus in our village.”Zabihullah Mujahid, another Taliban spokesman, said fighters were encouraging people to listen to health workers and messages broadcast by Mullahs, and would force anyone not obeying to comply.“Our Mujahideen are helping the health workers to spread out the messages about the dangers of Covid-19 among the public in our controlled areas,” he said.Religious scholars would also be consulted over whether gatherings in mosques should be suspended if the health scare intensified, he added.Trump to workers hit by coronavirus: ‘Money will soon be coming’A Taliban commander in southern Helmand province said the group would provide what services it could for people who became infected, but added that they neither had adequate facilities nor trained personnel to deal with an epidemic.Along with two other commanders that Reuters spoke with, he said the Taliban had clinics where sick or wounded fighters were taken for treatment.Otherwise, some Afghan non-government organisations are operating in insurgency-prone areas.Waheed Omer, an aide to President Ashraf Ghani, said he was still seeing reports of Taliban harassing health workers in some areas.“It should be stopped immediately,” he Tweeted on Wednesday.&nbspShare your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Three per cent of residents reportedly tested positive at firstA Italian village that was a&nbspcoronavirus hotspot has seen no new cases for days following blanket testing on all residents, according to local media.When around 3,300 people were checked for the virus in Vo Euganeo in northern Italy,&nbsp3 per cent (around 90) were infected with Covid-19, researchers said.&nbspMost of these&nbspreportedly had no symptoms of the flu-like disease at all.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“If he hadn’t have done this,”&nbspthe head of the Veneto region said, “Vo&nbspEuganeo&nbspwould have seen an explosion of infections.”Luca Zaia told Italian TV that the community was now “as healthy as can be”.&nbspHow to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?No new positive cases have been reported in the small Italian village since last week after authorities even tested asymptomatic people, according to newspaper Il Gazzettino.&nbsp​The mass-testing - a trial led by the University of Padua&nbsp- saw all residents checked for Covid-19 in February&nbspand then checked again shortly after.&nbspIt was hailed a success by researchers, who told local media that on the second round of testing, the number of positive results dropped significantly to 0.3 per cent.&nbsp“We were able to show that isolating all the positive cases allowed us to reduce the rate of infection,” Professor Andrea Crisanti&nbspsaid.“The real problem is asymptomatic people who test positive,” he&nbsptold&nbspItalian TV.&nbsp“If we continue to let them wander around, we will never get rid of the epidemic.”“I think that for every case that goes to hospital, there are more or less 10 people without symptoms.”Mr Zaia, Veneto’s governor,&nbspsaid the trial was “criticised by most sides” but that isolating numbers of undetected positive cases&nbsphas resulted in Vo Euganeo being today the safest place in Italy”.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: government reassure pregnant mums coronavirus
story: It is not the Government’s responsibility to calm the nation’s nerves on every one.But Britain’s expectant mums are entitled to more reassurance than they are getting after the latest disturbing news.First a newborn baby in London catches the deadly bug, then several others show symptoms at a hospital in Leeds.Hundreds of thousands of worried mothers-to-be now want to know that their tots cannot get the virus in the womb and that it is safe to breastfeed.At the moment the official advice is that breastfeeding is low-risk eventhe mum has the virus.But the chances of passing it on afterwards must be very high.And Ministers have been slow to come forward and calm fears in the face of the latest scares.Such confusion breeds anxiety.We back Boris Johnson and his scientic advisers in handling a crisis unprecedented in peacetime.But the PM and his top team need to be on the front foot every day.He has bravely gone against the tide of other countries by delaying extreme measures to clamp down on the bug.But as France and Spain went into lockdown he will now come under terric pressure to follow suit.As infection and death rates surge, he must keep making the case for relying on the scientic evidence.The majority of the public have supported him on this so far.He has to explain every step or risk losing their confidence and giving the social media bleaters a field day.It hasn’t helped that he has performed a U-turn by saying one day that large public gatherings can continue and the next they are to be banned.Butanyone can instil self belief in the country it is Boris Johnson.For a new Prime Minister this is a monumental challenge and one which will define his premiership.As long as he keeps his nerve Britain can come through this an even stronger nation.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus uk live news latest updates
story: MINISTERS have today revealed sweeping new coronavirus laws - with the powers to arrest sick people and even shut down airports.The emergency bill comes as the UKs cases of coronavirus rise to , and the death toll hits .But the government says there is zero chance of banning London travel - as pubs could be closed in the fight against coronavirus, Downing Street says.No slapped down speculation the capital would be put into lockdown - insisting there were no plans to confine people to their homes.Read our live blog for all the latest coronavirus news and updates.Kids entitled to free school dinners will be given vouchers or meals during the coronavirus outbreak, the Government has said.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said no child should go without food while their school is closed or they are self-isolating.There are around . million children who are entitled to free school meals.New guidance says schools will be able to provide meals or vouchers for supermarkets and shops.It will be up to schools to decide how to support these children.The Bank of England has slashed its key interest rate to .%, its lowest-ever level, as coornavirus sparks global economic turmoil.The banks Monetary Policy Committee says the unanimous decision is part of moves #to meet the needs of U.K. businesses and households in dealing with the associated economic disruption.#The new cuts come a week after the central bank cut its rate from .% to .%.The number of UK coronavirus deaths has risen to . It comes as the number of confirmed cases across Britain reached  today.Prince Albert of Monaco has tested positive for coronavirus.A man suspected of shoplting has been arrested after coughing on store staff and claiming to be infected with Covid-. West Midlands Police said a -year-old male was detained on suspicion of theft and assault in Dudley on Thursday afternoon.In a statement, officers said: #The man, who is from Dudley and has suspected mental health issues, has been taken into custody and will be questioned in due course.#Those affected have been given appropriate advice and referred to the non-emergency NHS helpline for further support and guidance.#Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: not time discredit government coronavirus strategy
story: Instead, a handful of broadcasters used precious air time to promote a motley crew of “scientists” desperately hoping to make their names discrediting the Government’s strategy.To those who don’t understand virology, not taking the same draconian measures as other countries may seem odd.But the Prime Minister is acting on the advice of Sir Patrick Vallance and Chris Whitty — eminent doctors ideally equipped to deal with the pandemic.Of course, their superior expertise shouldn’t exempt them from all scrutiny.And, given the stakes, the Government MUST publish the details of its modelling to put minds at rest and give expert virologists a chance to have their say.But puffed-up PhD students with an axe to grind are a far cry from professional epidemiologists.And British broadcasters should know better than to let them spread panic.ACCESS to education is one of the pillars of a civilised society.But because schools are excluding weaker pupils to avoid poor results harming their position in the league tables, a growing number of children are denied that basic right.The consequences of this folly are enormous.It’s estimated that every year-group of permanently excluded pupils costs us £.billion extra on education, health and welfare benefits.And, just as worryingly,  per cent of children in young offender institutions had been excluded while  per cent of prisoners were suspended or excluded.We get that children who struggle academically can be tough on over-stretched teachers.But education shouldn’t be about survival of the fittest.And it’s often the weakest pupils who need school most.Dumping them on the scrapheap of society isn’t fair on anyone.AMID horror and uncertainty, British people are displaying extraordinary kindness, camaraderie and bravery.Each time the Government announces it’s taking another step to keep us safe, Brits have demonstrated that they are listening — and understand the gravity of the situation.Instead of complaining about missed holidays and football games, they’ve quickly and quietly got on with what needs to be done. Shopkeepers — worrying about their own futures — have given out free hand sanitiser and tinned goods to elderly locals.Neighbours have rallied around those most at risk from the disease.This — not needless shelf-clearing — is Britain at its best. Our journalists strive for accuracy title: unitas youth centre loneliness prince harry onside
story: The -year-olds confidence was in tatters and she found it near impossible to talk to anyone - until one day she summoned up the courage to try a new youth centre nearby.Had you put me in this position a few months ago, or this time last year - no chance, she tells Sun Online, as she today sits beaming in front of the camera.I wouldn’t be able to, because I didn’t have the confidence for it.The £.million centre, which opened its doors in June last year, is now a home away from home for , kids around Barnet, North London.As part of the network of OnSide Youth Zones backed by Prince Harry, it was thrust into the limelight this month when he vowed to continue his support despite quitting royal duties - making it one of the first charities he has publicly committed to in his new le.Here, we shine a light on the young people it helps.When she first arrived at the centre, Samiya wouldnt speak to anyone outside the music room — the only place she felt comfortable.But she was blown away by what was on offer.For just p a visit, kids aged eight to  can come to Unitas and use its rooftop football pitch, record an album, learn to cook, use a gym, and scale a climbing wall.I was pretty heavily bullied during my time at school, says Samiya. I can laugh now but it resulted in me leaving that school that I was in.I was lonely at the time. But the timelines kind of fit perfectly with me leaving school and Unitas opening.”Slowly but surely, Samiya started venturing into the facilitys other rooms, trying her hand at art or taking part in the games played in the sports hall.Over several months, she felt more herself again.Everyone is so lovely, really and truly, I’m not just saying this, Samiya says. It’s in the name. Its the unity, you know Like all OnSide Youth Zones, Unitas was set up to give opportunities to kids in deprived areas that werent previously open to them.Its name, chosen by young people, comes from the Latin motto of Barnet — unitas efficit ministerium or unity accomplishes services.Child poverty in the nearby wards of Burnt Oakand Colindaleare higher than the national average of  per cent.Woodhouse and Childs Hill also have a third or more of their children living in poverty after housing costs are considered, according to data from the End Child Poverty Coalition.Taylor Dawson is another regular whos been coming to the centre since last summer — something which he never thought hed do.He used to be so anxious that he would never leave his house unless he absolutely had to - but Unitas changed him.The -year-old now helps out with the centres sessions run on Sundays for people with additional needs.“Some can come in with autism, ADHD, anything on the spectrum, Taylor tells Sun Online.“I have additional needs myself. It helps really well, so I know how to help the other kids as well.But its not just others who Taylor is helping — hes helping himself.“It’s helped really well with my confidence, because I never used to leave my house because I’ve got anxiety, Taylor said.So I’d never leave, I’d never go out with my friends. The only place I would go is the shop and back.Taylor loves that he now has a fruitful alternative - and hes noticed a dference in the lives of others around him too.All the kids who used to roam the streets, that attitude is not nice, he said.My mum won’t put down the picture of me with him, Latoya McLean says of a photo of her with Prince Harry.The heartwarming snap was taken last year after Latoya received the Giving Back award on stage at the Royal Albert Hall during the inaugural OnSide Awards.Her prize was for young people that have gone above and beyond for their youth centre and their community”.The -year-old has been involved with Unitas since the planning stages and is now one of the centres leading figures.For Latoya, joining Unitas was all about transcending the expectations that other people had for her and her peers.Young people are seen in such a bad perspective that I think they live up to what’s expected of them, Latoya said.They never push past that boundary. Society makes boxes and expects every young person to tick it.So I guess thats why I wanted to join the group — to reach my true potential and find what I was meant to be.As members enter Unitas, theyre searched for blades and other weapons with metal detectors as they step over the threshold.Its for their own protection — one of the centres main aims is to offer kids a safe place to go.For some of the people that we work with, they might have experienced quite traumatic events growing up in their childhood — things like domestic violence, abuse, Tony says.Some young people, they’re trying to move away from a le on the road and certain types of criminality.The existence of centres in deprived areas can also have positive effects for the wider area.Members can get a hot meal for £ — full-sized portions of fish and chips are on offer during Sun Onlines visit.One parent commented to one of my staff colleagues that their food bill had come down signicantly through the course of the week because they have three or four children who come here,” Tony says. “Beyond that, local residents comment on how young people feel better about the area that they live in, that the regeneration of the wider area has made them feel more confident — and you see that in their behaviour.”A local that can attest to that is Pat Furniss, , who grew up near where Unitas now stands.The mum-of-two, who used to work as a teacher, is now on the youth centres reception and is treated as a de facto auntie by the kids.I just love seeing and hearing the laughter, I think,” Pat says. She used to hear children laughing in the streets outside her home where she grew up — but she doesn’t hear it there so much anymore. Pat added: “I actually gave up working full-time to come and work here in the evenings.And as I say to the kids, I ain’t going nowhere! I’ll be here with my zimmer frame.” The kind of remarkable changes that Tony and Pat have witnessed arent unique to Unitas in Barnet.Wherever an OnSide Youth Centre Opens, remarkable things start to happen.Antisocial behaviour in the area drops between  and  per cent almost instantly, within a month or two,” says John Roberts, Chairman of OnSides Executive Board.Truancy drops and academic rates go up for the kids that attend the youth centre — none of this is rocket science.John thinks the benefits of his youth centres are so urgent that every town in the UK should have one, in the same way that it would have a school or a GP surgery.Many of the young people who currently benefit from its centres feel a lack of societal interest could be because their generation has been misunderstood and looked down upon by others.I just think this youth centre is building up the next generation to change how society feels, Latoya says.The future is safe, she adds.We’re not going to destroy what has been built before us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc sport relief charity finishes
story: The first was to postpone it, like the football and rugby, until such time as the theatre plugs and worthy schemes about “bringing the outside world to pensioners” with breathing dficulties, looked a bit less reckless.The second was to say: “Stuff it, as a one-off gesture to the British public, at this time of crisis, every single penny raised will be spent in Britain.”But Auntie would no more do that than re-run all eight series of Love Thy Neighbour, in The One Show’s slot.So they took option C and just ploughed on regardless, from pm, Friday, with the usual too-many-cooks line-up of Paddy McGuinness, Alex Scott and Gary Lineker, who made this earnest pledge: “We promise we’ll spend tonight’s money with such care on the most vulnerable.”Well, you’d hope so, wouldn’t you. And you’d also hope they take more care than they did with the actual production, which started to betray a “will-this-do ” attitude with almost its first caption of the night.“Dermot Munaghan.” And the next one: “Colston Smith.” .A foretaste of what was to come, because the event had technically unravelled within the first hour when Lineker had to introduce a comedy sketch about VAR and the  World Cup final.First it appeared, then it vanished. So Lineker explained the punchline: VAR had not just found in England’s favour it had decided to award the  World Cup to Scotlandand Euro  to Wales.Then the sketch suddenly reappeared again and took six minutes to reach its bloody, teeth-pulling conclusion: “I’m going to change my name to Jamie VAR-dy.”In such circumstances, you can sit and hope the rest of Sport Relief moves, inspires and thrills with a perfect blend of laughter, compassion and entertainment.And I can also hope Scotland are going to win the next World Cup. It ain’t going to happen.Sport Relief is never ever over quickly, ’cos there are a whole load of BBC formats to be put through the ringer, like Line Of Duty, and far too much dancing, featuring everyone from Lineker and McGuinnes to a “social media influencer”, called “HRVY”, which wasn’t another spelling mistake. I think he’s just an RSHOL.At ious other points in this back-of-a-fag-packet evening: Hockey player Sam Quek took , football penalties against a short fat bloke, from point-blank range, and contrived to miss more than a quarter of them. Mel Giedroyc farted on a Question Of Sport special. Rylan accused Romesh Ranganathan of being over-exposed, before playing Andy Murray at crazy golf. And they flagged up an Action Line number, for people who were feeling “emotionally vulnerable”, after the Killing Steves parody, which may have been the most benevolent gesture in the event’s history.What really irks about Sport Relief, though, is that, evencompassion fatigue has never been more of a problem, they’ve decided it’s a triumph before it’s broadcast and the “Best Bits” Sunday show is all ready to go.Corporate backing also means there’s little risk of them not beating the previous total either, which, I hope, doesn’t sound like I’m diminishing the sincere efforts of the public.If there’s one thing I’ll remember about Sport Relief , however, it’s the contribution of David Beckham, who, infor a y advertorial for his new MLS franchise and some crashing product placement , offered two entire people the chance to attend an Inter Miami game and win a shirt signed by such global talents as Lewis Morgan and A J DeLaGarza, who’s played  entire games for Guam.There are moments when the generosity and humanity of celebrities simply overwhelms me.This wasn’t one of those moments.Bloke.CHANNEL  seemed to have all bases covered for its hugely entertaining new dating show Five Guys A Week, at least in terms of complete bellends.So, crammed into a semi-detached house in St Albans, hoping to win the heart of its owner Amy, it had: Christian, whose job “isn’t as glamorous as it sounds” . Uber-woke Glen, from accounts. A stuntman called Michael, who seemed to have mistaken the show for SAS: Who Dares Wins and voluntarily withdrew on day two. Mad, goggle-eyed surfer Trystan, who appeared to be casing the joint for a “kill room”. And the lowest form of le known to any single thirtysomething man – the bloke with the acoustic guitar, Scott, who used to be a bank manager, but now earns a living as a country and western singer and will be performing under the stage name Johnny Cashpoint,he’s got an ounce of sense.The five were chosen for their ability to get right on the viewers’ nerves rather than real boyfriend potential, obviously.And it made for a cracking hour of TV, because they all competitively fancied the pants off Amy, who looked like a younger and much hotter Camilla Parker Bowles,you can imagine such a thing.The show’s greatest strength, of course, is also its biggest format failing, as I’d imagine no one wanted any of them to win.In the event, however, it came down to a straight fight between the lesser of two evils and, probably wisely, Amy chose cocky Christian, who’s looking to whisk her off for breakfast in France, ahead of grovelling Glen, who, rather than looking for “the Michelle Obama to my Barack”, should probably be aiming for the Michelle Collins to his Ian Beale.Five Guys A Week, C, tonight, .pm.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What caused the cancellation of six Wimbledon championships in the s ”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in north-east England shares its common name with the body of a ship ”Spin To Win, Phillip Schofield: “What Saturday night TV show is Anton du Beke most famous for ”Hunted, Dan: “Who painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel ”LISA NANDY wasn’t born stupid. She volunteered to be, by standing for Labour Party leader.It means noisily backing every woke cause of the day, until their interests collide, as they did spectacularly on last Tuesday’s Good Morning Britain, where Piers Morgan hit her with two innocuous-sounding questions.“Are babies born either male or female ” and “Would you be happyUsain Bolt and Floyd Mayweather self-identied as women, spent a year having testosterone treatment and competed against women ”Correct answers: Yes and no.But Lisa couldn’t say that for fear of offending either the transgender or feminist lobbies.So instead she blathered, lied, evaded, shouted, demanded an apology from Piers , accused him of laughing and describing transgender people as “grotesque”and at one point muttered: “I don’t know what . . . I don’t know what, well, you know, I don’t know what.”Others would’ve let her off the hook at that point, as she was almost crying at her own stupidity by then. Chunk didn’t.To his eternal credit he ignored two ad breaks and kept up the pressure for a spellbinding  minutes that only ended when Nandy offered to settle the issue of whether Floyd Mayweather should be able to box women by “setting up a commission”.To which Piers responded: “It’s not a commission issue, it’s a common sense issue.”But that, as a wise man once said, is the problem with common sense, Piers. It’s not all that common.Ian Wright: “At this stage, I think three points is three points.”Jamie Redknapp: “Switching off from football is always beneficial sometimes.”Piers Morgan effectively ending Lisa Nandy’s Labour leadership bid on TV’s most consistently entertaining show, Good Morning Britain.Saturday night eye balm from BBC’s Ireland: Edge Of The World. Larry David ending up in the “ugly section” of Tiato’s restaurant, on Curb Your Enthusiasm.Sky’s Breeders managing to make a comedy about children bearable.And John Humphrys’ opening curveball on Saturday’s Celebrity Mastermind: “Name ” “Bez.” “Occupation ” Pass.This Morning, Holly Willoughby: “What should a ‘support neighbour’ look like  ’Cos my mum’s older than me.”Andyour mum isn’t older than you, self-isolate immediately.THIS week’s winner is Future Stewie, from Family Guy, and Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty.All those self-defined “experts” whose coronavirus response is framed not by their humanity or expertise but the desperate need to be proved right.Every selfish moron in the country being filmed panic-buying toilet rolls.Firebrand left-wing stand-up Guz Khan taking the gig economy advertising shilling from Uber Eats.The comically awful use of Photoshopped throwback pictures in BBC drama The Split.And the never-ending queue of fantasists and egomaniacs at E’s Sex Clinic, like third person-speaking Drew, who announced: “I’m not having vanilla sex. That’s not what the Drew brand is about. Le’s too short, man.” The shorter the better . . . man.The Sex Clinic, Matt: “I think I need to learn to love myself.”Five Guys A Week, Glen: “My talents aren’t obvious. They’re not tangible things.” On account of the fact they don’t exist. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trust health service staff coronavirus
story: All along he has followed the best advice of our foremost experts on ­epidemics. They said that would evolve as the situation worsened — and yesterday it was toughened dramatically.National unity is key. We must take to heart the self-isolation and lockdowns — both for those already with symptoms and those without. Likewise the “advice” not to go to pubs, restaurants or cinemas.Our lives will be very dferent for months. Britain will barely resemble the country we love. But we can all play our part in seeing off this catastrophe, minimising the disease’s spread and giving the NHS every chance to save lives.The Sun will raise just one doubt:It still seems inconsistent that families must avoid non-essential social contact, but continue packing the children off to school. We know the NHS would be hit hardhealth workers stayed home to look after their kids. But a school skeleton staff could surely supervise them.Only the wartime generation has experienced a crisis this grave. We have to put our faith politically in the newly elected government tasked with facing it down — and the experts around them.Even more importantly we must trust our health service and back its magnicent and selfless staff. You can do that today by emailing iloveNHS@the-sun or by using the form below. We’ll print your messages.The NHS will need every ounce of support the nation can give, evenit just means dutully staying put in our homes.  THE six days since the Budget seem like ten years.Chancellor Rishi Sunak’s admirable debut last Wednesday is all but irrelevant. Its apparently huge bailouts to mitigate the virus will be nowhere near enough. Its growth forecasts are toast.Britain’s decisive response, including the Bank of England slashing the base rate hours earlier, was praised around the world. Others followed suit. But vastly more will now be needed.Evenit lasts no more than a few months — still a big— Covid- is a gargantuan shock to the global economy.Hundreds of thousands of healthy businesses here face oblivion. Their workers may face the dole. Major ­airlines could go bust within weeks.The Government will have to borrow staggering sums to keep them afloat — dishing out grants, tax breaks, business rates relief, interest-free loans, boosted sick pay and more.But we will add this: This is a ­calamity we must ALL face together.If corporations make staff take the pain while fatcat execs sail through it financially unscathed, there will be hell to pay.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
