title: coronavirus thinking revive blitz spirit
story: People have lost loved ones and will continue to do so, and the virus is going to cause an unprecedented, global economic crisis that could see businesses go under, job losses, and severe financial dficulty for those already living hand to mouth.You’ll no doubt have read the latest bad news.So, solely for the purposes of this article, forgive me , instead, I focus momentarily on trying to find the admittedly few green shoots poking through the rubble.For, unlike Brexitwhich caused bitter ision among communities, the coronavirus pandemicis already bringing communities together that, in the modern age of “smart” devices absorbing our attention, had perhaps become slightly detached from each other in recent years.Professor Steven Taylor, author of The Psychology of Pandemics, says: “People need reminding that they can cope with this. They are resilient. You aren’t going to like it, but you’ll get through it.“You can compare it to the Blitz. People got through the Blitz. It was very stressful but they did it.”My elderly mother lives just a few roads away from me and, like so many with similarly vulnerable relatives, I’m making sure she’s OK.“Just pop a tin of Spam through the letterbox, and I’ll be fine,” she joked in reference to her time growing up during World War Two.But yesterday, three of her immediate neighbours — one of whom she’s never met — put notes through her door to say she should give them a callshe needed anything.In times of such crisis, our first thought is naturally of ourselves and our immediate loved ones.But it seems the upsideof the world slowing down and re-grouping might be that, no longer distracted by the busyness of our normal working days, we will “look up” and “reach out”, as they say in business circles, to those in our communities who might need help.There are plenty of people who already do sterling work in their area, but the onslaught of the coronavirus will perhaps lead to everyone now doing their bit.Quite right too. But the onus can’t solely rest on the shoulders of iniduals, so it’s only right the Government has stepped up to offer some practical help to businesses that will suffer throughout the coming weeks and months.Boris Johnson’s advice that people shouldn’t go to pubs cafes theatres etc is understandable in health terms, but will leave businesses facing a critical downturn in custom through no fault of their own.Yesterday, London restaurateur James Chiaini urged him to “crack open the war chest” and allow local businesses to stay afloat while simultaneously channelling efforts towards helping out in their immediate communities, and it seems that new Chancellor Rishi Sunak has listened.In James’s case, he has staff on hand and lots of food supplies, so instead of shutting down because there are no customers, he and other restaurants across the country could potentially now operate a batch-cooking and delivery service for those in need.Equally, the skill sets of many other businesses can be channelled into providing much-needed, state-funded help where it’s required.And the Government shouldn’t stop there. It should repurpose certain facilities too.Last week, it was reported that the £million Defence Medical Rehabilitation Centre in Loughborough, Leics, is currently seriously underused because only current personnel can access it and only  have done so in the past  months.Madness. At the very least, it should be thrown open to all injured veterans who currently have to go through the overstretched NHS.Or how about temporarily repurposing it as a treatment centre for anyone who could benefit from its facilities, thereby alleviating some of the pressure on local hospitals The Government is clearly in uncharted territory right now because it is dealing with an unprecedented situation.But a continuation of joined-up thinking on how best to get us through this critical phase in our history will ensure that Britain’s enviable “Blitz spirit” is encouraged and kept strong for as long as it needs to be.PRINCE Harry is now back behind the closed doors of his rented Canadian mansion, licking his wounds after his public humiliation at the hands of phone pranksters.During a chat with what he thought was climate change activist Greta Thunberg and her father, Harry pledged his support to the non-existent island of “Chunga-Changa” and failed to question why the hoaxers wanted to ship penguins to the North Pole when they’re actually native to the South Pole.Poor Harry.Still, it perhaps explains why, despite attending Eton, he got D at geography A level.Indeed, on all our faces in these challenging times.Heartfelt congratulations to her and husband Chris.FORMER All Saints star Nicole Appleton has given birth to her second child, a girl called Skipper, at the age of .“After hiding my pregnancy for the last nine months – which was so dficult and keeping her a secret from all my friends – I can finally announce our incredible news!” she wrote on Instagram.Fascinating. It’s one thing wearing a big coat out in public, but how do you hide a growing bump from “friends” Has Nicole, whose boyfriend is Stephen Haines, been in pre-emptive self-isolation for the past few months Or is it simply that her petite frame and enviably taut stomach muscles meant she just looked like the rest of us after a big meal Personally speaking, by month seven I looked like I had a medicine ball stuffed up my frock.STORMZY reportedly ripped up his travel plans after meeting Victoria’s Secret model Yasmine Aisha Khala Holmgren backstage at a gig in Stockholm.The pair are said to have holed up in a hotel room for two days where, according to a friend of the grime star, they wanted to spend “quality time” together.That’s one way of putting it.A NEW biography about former Commons Speaker John Bercow claims that he didn’t speak to a female aide for the entirety of a nine hour flight – because he was furious that his toothpaste had been confiscated at airport security.Quite what it had to do with her is anyone’s guess.But one imagines she was grateful for the prolonged period of peace.HANNAH SMITH, a -year-old mum of one, has been handed a suspended sentence after admitting the crime of harbouring a criminal.Her boyfriend, violent robber Luke Harvey, scaled the wall of HMP Sudbury in Derbyshire, where Hannah was waiting to drive him to Skegness for a weekend away.They were later pulled over by police and Harvey, , had ten months added to the -year sentence he received in .Leicester Crown Court was told that the couple had now split up.Presumably, actually spending time together proved too much.HERE is yet another photograph of the singer and actress Jenner Lopez looking sensational at . Sigh.Apparently, this latest photo-shoot, which highlights her enviably toned and tanned legs in a tuxedo-style leotard, is to promote her new footwear line.Is she wearing shoes We hadn’t noticed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: historic images keep calm carry on brits ww2
story: POIGNANT black and white photos taken during World War Two demonstrate the keep calm and carry on Blitz spirit of Brits during the s.Striking footage shows British people playing, laughing, joking and going to parties, even as they feared a Luftwaffe bombing.The country remained defiant as it endured months of German bombing.Between September  and May , , people were killed in the bombing raids - , of them children.Nazi planes dropped , tonnes of bombs on Britain during the Blitz.But these photos show cheerful faces as le went on despite the chaos and terror.The images show people working together to overcome their panic and help repair the devastation caused during the campaign.Government officials even said Brits were generally ‘cheerful’, ‘highly confident’ and ‘taking the bombing with good heart’, despite the staggering loss of le.The images are relevant - and inspiring - as coronavirus panic sweeps the UK  years on.Millions of people are currently working from home as offices shut down, while railways and major roads fall silent and panic-buyers empty supermarket shelves of essential items.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.

title: spot huge carpet python hiding familys kitchen larder
story: Queenslander Stuart McKenzie floored Aussies by challenging them to find the hiding place of a sneaky carpet python - which can grow up to  feet.On the Sunshine Coast Snake Catchers Facebook page, he posted a pic of the well-concealed constrictor, inviting people to Spot the Snake.Stuart added: Amongst all the [coronavirus] panic I think a good old fashion game of Spot the Snake is what we all need. See how you go finding this one and bonus pointsyou can guess the species.We will continue to provide a   snake catching services across the whole Sunshine Coast, Noosa and Deception Bay areas despite the CoronaVirus. Snakes dont stop for no virus [sic]. We will start employing distancing at snake calls but lets be honest we already make sure our customers stand well clear of us when we are catching the snakes.In the end, he received more than  comments, as people puzzled over the stealthy creatures whereabouts.A defeated Phil Trevan replied: I hate spot the snake, I have never worked out one yet.Others responded by circling potential hiding spots. Bob Trezise joked: Top right, deadly green tinsel adder   while a stumped Connie Carey posted its a goodie. Cannot see it.Jo Helenius begged: Answer pls it is doing my head in lol.In the end Stuart relented, and provided the answer - the carpet python was hiding between cardboard and plastic storage boxes.Shahni Waerea replied: The moral of this story is... snakes love clutter.They live in open forests, rainforests, coastal heaths, rural lands, park lands and suburban gardens.Active both day and night, carpet pythons can be encountered on the ground, in trees or buildings - particularly chicken pens, barns and attics.Athough non-venomous, tetanus protection is recommended following bites.Male Carpet Snakes have been observed fighting in spring.The species feed on frogs, lizards, birds, mammals, and can grow up to .m long.Source: Queensland Museum  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sanders suspends campaign after latest defeat to joe biden on super tuesday iii
story: The Vermont Senator reportedly showed extreme anger when he was questioned about his campaign plans by a CNN reporter on Wednesday.When CNNs Senior Congressional Correspondent Manu Raju asked the -year-old, he replied:  Im dealing with a f***ing global crisis. You know, were dealing with.According to Rajus tweets, Sanders then added: “Well right now, right now I’m trying to do my best to make sure that we don’t have an economic meltdown and that people don’t die.“Is that enough for you to keep me busy for today ”Sanders lost his temper in the middle of a five-minute gaggle about the unprecedented crisis of our le time, Raju said in a followup tweet.The reporter said the Democratic presidential hopeful was calling for a number of steps that the US government should take in the midst of the economic crisis.Sanders angry response comes after his team denied a report he is ending his campaign after suspending all of his Facebook ads in the wake of his latest defeat.It was reported the radical Democratic Socialist ended his bid for the US presidency after being beaten by Biden, according to a Bloomberg News reporter.The Fidel Castro-praising politician suffered huge losses to Biden, who won Arizona, Florida and Illinois.However, his campaign aides refuted claims he called it quits on Twitter today.Sanders Communications Director Mike Casca described them as absolutely .The claims emerged after Axios noted his campaign has no active Facebook ads - the morning after his disappointing results in primary bids.Bernies campaign manager previously Faiz Shakir issued a statement saying he would be assessing his campaign.Shakir said last night did not go the way we wanted, after Bernie lost three states, according to Axios.The report noted former presidential hopefuls Pete Buttigieg and Michael Bloomberg deactivated their Facebook ads before pulling out of the race.Despite his numerous gaffes on the campaign trail, Bidens latest victory marks the third consecutive week he has piled up wins after South Carolina last month revived his once-weakened campaign.Sanders recent comments about Cuba probably doomed him there weeks ago, well before Bidens South Carolina surge.In a  Minutes interview on February , Sanders praised Cuban dictator Castro for his massive literacy program. The -year-old Vermont senator has continued to push on in the  presidential race despite a string of losses to Biden.The coronavirus pandemic has also impacted both Bernie and Bidens rallies as Americans are urged to avoid large gatherings.Last week, Sanders vowed to do everything in his power to stop Donald Trump in his six-minute televised address in Vermont.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mobile morgue westminster london coronavirus
story: A HUGE mobile mortuary has been swtly set up in London to cope with the number of bodies from the coronavirus pandemic.It comes as cases in the UK surged to , with  deaths, as the Prime Minister urged everyone to work from home.Westminster Public Mortuary has space for  bodies, but the expanded tent set up will see this almost doubled - as London becomes the worst hit.Today builders were seen at the site behind Westminster Coroners Court readying for a jump in expected victims.A Westminster council worker at the site today, said the refrigerated racked tent would double the councils capacity.He also said councils were building similar tents to expand capacity as much as possible in the pandemic.Adding: The tent will be up today and will be ready by the weekend.We hopefully wont ever need them. But you saw the numbers of what could happen, so we need to be prepared.A Westminster City Council spokesperson added: We have plans in place to increase the capacity of our mortuary at Horseferry Road as part of a London wide response to the Coronavirusoutbreak.This is a precautionary step and similar arrangements are made during any London wide response to incidents. We hope and trust that this will not be needed but it is sensible to prepare at this stage.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.London is braced to enter a lockdown within days - with extra travel restrictions for Brits in the capital.Sources close to City Hall say the Government is preparing a fresh bill to give them the power to stop gatherings, and keep Londoners inside.The over s, those who are pregnant, and anyone with underlying health conditionsshould try not to leave their homesthey can, and avoid crowded spaces immediately.This will continue for the “long haul” – likely weeks or months.And those with severe illnesses like cancermust start cocooning themselves in their homes and get food delivered in from this weekend.Earlier this week Boris Johnson said: Clearly what we’re announcing today is a very substantial change in the way we want people to live their lives, and I can’t remember anything like it in my letime.I don’t think there’s really been anything like it in peacetime.It’s a very considerable, psychological, behavioural change that we’re asking you, we’re asking the public, the nation to do.But I’ve absolutely no doubt that we can do it, that we can do it together.A team from Imperial College London, led by Professor Neil Ferguson, said the new tighter controls could limit deaths to around , - with the leading professor admitting the best case scenario would still see tens of thousands die.The country could be stuck in a state of permanent outbreak and lockdown until a vaccine is found - title: coronavirus school closures uk closed
story: SCHOOLS across England, Scotland and Wales will be closed by the end of the week as Britain desperately tries to contain the coronavirus outbreak. Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Wednesday that he would be closing tens of thousands of schools this Friday due to the crisis.The closures will start this Friday afternoon, with no lessons planned once theyve left.Schools will be closed for normal pupils, but kept open for the children of key workers.This means parents working in the NHS, emergency services and other essential fields will still be able to send their kids off while they work.The move comes two weeks before kids are meant to break up for the Easter break.And they may not reopen before the six-week summer break too, with the Education Secretary today saying they would be closed until further notice.Schools will be closed for at least five weeks.Mr Williamson announced the closures this evening, and claimed keeping schools open would no longer be in the best interests of children and teachers.He explained the scientic evidence had changed,  and the move was at the forefront of Britains fightback against the virus.The Tory MP also revealed assessments and exams  were both cancelled, and there will be performance tables this academic year.He said: This will be for all children except to those of key workers and children who are most vulnerable.The scientic evidence shows these settings are safe for this small number of children to continue attending.But asking others to stay away will go towards helping us slow the spread of this virus.Examples of these key workers include NHS staff, police and delivery drivers who need to be able to go to work.Schools in Scotland and Wales are to close from Friday because of the epidemic.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said schools had just lost too many staff to be able to carry on as normal.She also warned parents not to expect them to be back in time for the summer term.It comes after a second person died in Scotland after becoming infected.And schools in Wales will also be closed from March  after the coronavirus death toll hit  in the UK.Welsh education minister Kirsty Williams said: I can announce we are bringing forward the Easter break for schools in Wales.Schools across Wales will close for statutory provision of education at the latest on  March .I have been clear up to now that the continuity of education and the well-being of our learners has been at the heart of my decision making.

title: chinas coronavirus expert herd immunity
story: CHINA’S leading coronavirus expert has said the strategy of “herd immunity” will not work because the disease is too infectious.Dr Zhong Nanshan criticised the policy whereby where a large portion of the public are exposed to the disease in order to build up resistance.Englands chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said a herd immunity approach could be beneficial in preventing another more aggressive outbreak of Covid-.The thinking shaped the government’s decision to avoid draconian measures, such as the lockdown in Italy.But it has now dramatically changed tack and closed schools amid fears many more people than originally thought could die as the death toll reaches .“Herd immunity wont solve the problem,” said Dr Zhong.“We dont have the evidence to prove thatyou are infected once, you would be immune for le. Our next step is to develop effective vaccines, which requires global cooperation.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Last week Sir Patrick outlined the thinking behind the herd immunity approach, which he said was aimed at preventing the virus recurring.“We think this virus is likely to be one that comes year on year, becomes like a seasonal virus,” he said.Communities will become immune to it and thats going to be an important part of controlling this longer term.About  per cent is the sort of figure you need to get herd immunity.But Health Secretary Matt Hancock denied that was the Governments policy, describing it as a scientic concept.The approach had been criticised by a group of scientists from UK universities, who said it risks many more lives than necessary, and was called into question by the World Health Organisation.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Builder Steve Thomson, , and we Lenka, , are still in the cramped home, where their two sons share a room.The humble pair, who won one of Britain’s biggest jackpots in November, have finally decided what they want in their dream house — four bedrooms.Pals say they went to see a £million property but thought it was “over the top” and are determined not to buy a “flash” home.Instead the couple, who also have a daughter, want a modest, detached, four-bed in Sy, West Sussex, where they live.The winners’ lack of rush to move comes after grafter Steve, , ed to work and bought a van — second-hand.Steve is now thought to have quit work after honouring all the customers he was booked in for at the time of his win.One friend said: “They’re looking for a new home but they say they don’t want anything too flash.“They’re such a down-to-earth family, real gems, and they could buy a palacethey wanted to but they have said they want to stay in Sy.“Their only priority was to get a bedroom for each of their kids.”Another pal said: “The world is their oyster and they could afford anywhere but they are a very modest couple.”After their EuroMillions win Steve and corner shop worker Lenka, , pledged to “do things for the community” in their seaside town.The couple declined to comment.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: northern ireland veterans end witch hunts
story: The landmark offer is being drawn up by ministers as the next chapter in their election vow to end witch-hunt historical investigations, The Sun can reveal.It comes as Northern Ireland Secretary Brandon Lewis delighted ageing ex-troops by revealing he plans to rip up the vast majority of police probes into incidents during the Troubles, some of which date back five decades.The Cabinet minister said his action was to match a new law unveiled by the MoD today to slap a time limit of five years on legal pursuits of service personnel on overseas operations.Mr Lewis pledged “equal treatment of Northern Ireland veterans and those who served overseas”.He revealed he is setting up a new commission to rapidly st through the morass of outstanding accusations and claims.Its aim will be to give grieving families long-hoped for answers about their murdered loved ones, but at the same time offer closure to worried veterans in their s and s.Mr Lewis told the Commons in a written statement: “The Government will ensure that the investigations which are necessary are effective and thorough, but quick, so we are able to move beyond the cycle of investigations that has, to date, undermined attempts to come to terms with the past.”But introducing the crucial new caveat, he added: “Only cases in which there is a realistic prospect of a prosecution as a result of new compelling evidence would proceed to a full police investigation.“Cases which do not reach this threshold, or subsequently are not referred for prosecution, would be closed.”Dropping a major hint about his plan to then force their permanent closure in law, he added: “No further investigations or prosecutions would be possible”.The new body is likely to replace the controversial Historical Investigations Unit, which was set to go over more than  killings by ex-Army soldiers through out the conflicts  years.Ministers hope it will last for only one or two years, with outstanding cases against troops dealt with first and wrapped up in a matter of months.When they are closed, the intention is then to give each veteran involved in them a legal undertaking that they are in the clear forevermore - a process that could match the comfort letters sent to IRA terrorists exempting them from prosecution after the Good Friday peace deal in .The sweeping changes – which will be passed in legislation expected next month – would deliver on PM Boris Johnson’s election pledge to end vexatious claims against vets.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur title: rishi sunak coronavirus economy meltdown
story: Some have already lost their jobs. Others must now give theirs up to look after their kids, with schools closing.It may be hard for politicians to grasp, but many ordinary people have no savings to tide them over.They are broke NOW. They need to feed themselves and their families NOW.Not at the weekend. Not next week.Even those not yet made redundant by this global economic collapse are petried about how bad this could get.The pub industry alone says hundreds of thousands of jobs will be lost imminently without immediate help.Other governments have stepped in. Why has ours been so slow Devising a new system to get tens of billions in lost wages into the right hands is complex. We get that.We also think the “universal income” idea is an ill-considered and permanently ruinous fix.But promises, and a temporary ban on evicting renters, won’t quell the fear.This virus is not the fault of the workers, nor the Government whose draconian restrictions are sound.But with the economy in total meltdown, only the Government now can get Britain paid.Do it today, Rishi.CLOSING schools was grimly inevitable but right. It always seemed odd to keep them open while telling everyone to stay home.The Government must fulfil its pledge to ensure kids on free school meals are fully funded to get fed.We pay tribute to the NHS staff, delivery drivers and social carers whose often low-paid work is so essential that their children WILL still be looked after in school.And our hearts go out to the teenagers whose GCSEs and A-levels will be postponed indefinitely.This is an unprecedented nightmare, blighting their childhoods.We can only help each other endure it.IMAGINE the evil of using a deadly ­pandemic to spread fake news furthering your political or commercial agenda.It should no longer shock us after the Salisbury poisonings.But Kremlin trolls are sowing panic online to undermine the West’s Covid- strategies.Let’s remember that, next time our leaders have to make nice with Putin at the G.Meanwhile, conspiracy cranks say hand sanitiser causes cancer — and charlatans claim their “yoghurt suppositories” or vitamin pills “cure” the virus.Where do they do this with near impunity  That’s right . . .On Facebook, which talks such a good game about policing its site — but is always found wanting.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government 24 hours save britains pubs
story: THE Government has  hours to save Britain’s pubs, industry leaders have warned as they sent a four-pronged ultimatum.In a letter to the Chancellor The British Beer and Pub Association said thousands of pubs will go under and hundreds of thousands of jobs will be lost within days without immediate help from the Government.The industry body is demanding the Government underwrites at least  per cent of wages so pubs can keep staff on and easily reopen when social distancing restrictions are lted.It is also calling for immediate cancellation of beer duty bills and VAT payments that are due to be paid by March  for the last financial year.The BBPA is also asking Chancellor Rishi Sunak to immediately distribute the £, and £, cash grants promised to pub companies.And it is also demanding the Chancellor underwrites insurance costs for business interruption for a period of at least three months for the pub sector, with money being sent to insurers or to businesses directly.The industry body, which represents  per cent of Britain’s brewers and around , owners of pubs, warned Mr Sunak he has “no time to lose”.In the letter to Mr Sunak - titled “ hours to Save our Pub Industry” - BBPA chief Emma McClarkin warns: “Mass and permanent pub closures are absolutely inevitable in a matter of days without a meaningful support package.“Some of our members are already closing pubs and there is no guarantee that they will ever reopen. We don’t have weeks we have days to save the sector.”In a heartfelt plea she adds: “Pubs are the heart of the community and the social hub in all towns, villages and cities across the UK.“Urgent investment in our sector can deliver disproportionate s in this extremely worrying time.“The sector supports almost a million jobs across the country, many in less affluent areas.“These jobs are in imminent danger, companies will be required to act this week regarding redundancies. title: uk coornavirus lockdown summer doctor
story: BRITAINS coronavirus lockdown could be relaxed within about three months, according to a top doctor.Richard Horton, also the editor of scientic journal The Lancet, says he has seen research suggesting the restrictions might not be needed until we find a vaccine.Earlier this week government advisers warned the country could be stuck in limbo for up to  months, otherwise the virus mightwhen the extreme measures are lted.But Dr Horton said that we should look to what was happening in China, where cases have fallen and society is slowly coming back to normality.He told The Times: I think in the next month or so we are going to have good evidence that is going to give us a path for how we do eventually lt the restrictions as we come into the summer.“There’s no reason at all why we have to necessarily see a second wave of the epidemic.“This is a very active area of research right now. Research teams from other parts of the world who endured the epidemic are using their experience, and that can be extremely informative for how we will eventually lt these restrictions.“I think we will see these restrictions imposed for maybe two to three months and then, over the course of the summer, a very gradual staged relaxation of those restrictions which will take us into the autumn months.”Cases in the UK have risen to , with  deaths - London is faring the worst with almost , cases.The change in advice which sparked more severe restrictions came after new data from Italy showed the impact on the health service has been more serious than feared.Professor Neil Ferguson, director of the team at Imperial College which conducted the study, said: “It is likely such measures - most notably, large scale social distancing - will need to be in place for many months - perhaps until a vaccine becomes available.[It] was suppressed in China but we have no reason to believe its not what would happenwe did nothing. Slow spread would look at large number of deaths and health service being overwhelmed.These estimated were viewed as reasonable worst case. As information has been gathered in recent weeks, its become clear its not the reasonable worst case, but the most likely scenario.We are left with no option to adopt this more draconian strategy. He added the government got the timing of the lockdown just about right as it became unavoidable to no longer take stronger action.The Imperial report found the best course of action was a Chinese-style suppression policy implementing social distancing for the entire population.It comes as , troops are ready to join the fight against coronavirus as superspreader city London faces a total lockdown as early as Friday. The armed forces are poised to step in to take over hotels and run them as hospitals as the UKs death rate spirals and Prime Minister Boris Johnson prepares to deploy sweeping shutdown measures.Prof Ferguson said: We may well be ending up in a really quite dferent world for at least a year or more.“Really, the only exit strategy long term from this is vaccination or other forms of innovative technology which allows us to control transmission.”In dramatic actions not seen since World War Two, the PM drastically ramped up Britains battleplan on Monday - shutting down mass gatherings and urging everyone to stop non-essential travel and contact with others.And yesterday he said schools would be shut after tomorrow - with more details to come later today.He said that means all Britsstaying out of pubs, clubs, theatres and cinemas for weeks - and potentially months into the summer. All who can can should work from home, he said.The over s, those who are pregnant, and anyone with underlying health conditionsshould try not to leave their homesthey can, and avoid crowded spaces immediately.This will continue for the long haul - likely weeks or months.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen leaves london for windsor coronavirus
story: THE Queen was today pictured driving to Windsor Castle with her pet corgi # a week earlier than planned amid the coronavirus crisis.The -year-old monarch will stay in Windsor past Easter as health authorities work to contain the spread of the deadly bug.She was this morning seen casually dressed in a cardigan and a navy padded gilet, as she was driven away from Buckingham Palace.One of the Queen#s dorgis # she has two named Candy and Vulcan # could be seen next to her as they both looked out of the car window.And Prince Philip was choppered from Wood Farm in Sandringham to Windsor today to be with the Queen.The -year-old had always planned to be with her for Easter, with his schedule changed to match her revised plans.Her Majesty held one of her final engagements in London yesterday # shunning gloves but bowing instead of shaking hands with naval offices at Buckingham Palace.She also held her last face-to-face weekly audience with Prime Minister Boris Johnson.Confirming the Queen#s change of schedule earlier this week, Buckingham Palace announced: #Her Majesty will move to Windsor Castle for the Easter period on Thursday th March, one week earlier than planned.#It is likely The Queen will stay there beyond the Easter period.#And Prince Harry and Meghan Markle are still #desperately hoping# they will be able to visit in the summer to see the Queen despite the crisis.The Sussexes, who are currently in Canada, were due to head to Windsor Castle later this year with baby Archie # who the Queen has rarely seen.Several royal events will be postponed including all garden parties at the palace and the annual Maundy Service at St George’s Chapel on th April will not go ahead.To follow us on Facebook, simply #Like# our Coronavirus page.More than , people were set to gather at the palace for the traditional parties in May. Two more garden parties at organised by charities and hosted the palace have also been canned.Every guest who won a ticket through the ballot will instead be invited to the  garden parties.All major future engagements including Trooping the Colour and VE Day celebrations are under review.Meanwhile, Buckingham Palace today announced the Emperor and Empress of Japan had postponed their Spring visit to the UK.The death toll from coronavirus has now reached  in the UK with confirmed cases up to ,.Yesterday Boris Johnson announced schools will close from Friday with A-Level and GCSE exams cancelled.London#s transport lockdown will start from today with  Tube stations closed until further notice and the rest of the capital#s transport network to be scaled back dramatically.Further powers are also being looked at to keep people at home in the coming days and troops will be deployed in a bid to help the nation handle the escalating crisis.So far  people have been infected in London # more than  per cent of all confirmed cases in the country.Mr Johnson warned that #everything is on the table# as urgent talks were held to decideBritain will follow Italy, France and Spain in ordering people to stay indoors for up to  days.He also called for #ruthless# enforcement of social distancing measures and added: #Let#s be in no doubt these are very important choices we are making in our daily lives.#The more strictly, more ruthlessly, we can enforce upon ourselves and our families the advice we are getting, then the better we will be able to protect our NHS.#Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: confusions schools families coronavirus
story: Education Secretary Gavin Williamson yesterday announced kids who could still get lessons from next week would include all people working in schools and the NHS.The plans have already unravelled with parents who are helping to keep Britain running being rejected from the emergency coronavirus scheme.Despite claims it was open to everyone, schools are now using social media to warn parents both must be key workers to be eligible.Otherwise, one is expected to stay at home and look after them.It comes after Boris Johnson announced schools would shut their gates on Friday evening and likely not open up for months to come - possibly September.Certain will be allowed to send their kids in so they can carry on going to work.The list will include everyone working in the NHS in any way - and will likely include everyone from admin staff to cleaners.The same rule will apply for schools, with teaching assistants set to be on the list too.Delivery drivers who are taking vital supplies to the nations shops will be included.And anyone working in critical infrastructure like gas, electricity and other networks including transport will probably be allowed to send kids to school too.Environment Secretary George Eustice appeared to confirm this morning that all supermarket workers would be on the key list.Meanwhile:The Department for Education said police would be key workers as well.Mr Williamson told the BBC earlier: It will include all those people working within the NHS.We talk about doctors and nurses but there are so many more people who make sure a hospital is able to run and .All of those people will be included.There will also be the the need for those who work within schools, those who are providing the support in order for doctors and nurses, and those NHS staff to be able to get to those hospitals.More widely, we still need to have our critical infrastructure that continues to work and .Last night Boris announced the dramatic closure of all the nations schools as Britain desperately tries to contain the outbreak at the right time.The Education Secretary Gavin Williamson promised that free school meals will continue for everyone who needs it - likely in the form of supermarket vouchers.Boris told the nation this evening that the spread was slowing as a result of the draconian measures he put in place this week.The PM explained: We believe the steps we have already taken, together with those I am announcing today, are already slowing the spread of the disease.Exams will be cancelled too - but kids and teachers are confused as to how they will get their grades.Mr Williamson said this morning children will still be able to go on to university or college from the autumn - even though they havent sat their exams.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Mr Williamson said schools will be closed until further notice - but would be at least five weeks, taking us until April  at the earliest.The closure comes just two weeks before the Easter break when they would have had a fortnight off.But this break could last until the end of the school year and the summers six-week break.

title: army coronavirus ravaged italy corpses
story: TROOPS are now removing  bodies from a coronavirus-hit city which can no longer cope with the numbers dying.Army vehicles have been brought in to transport dozens of coffins from Bergamo to cities and towns across the north of Italy.The wealthy city - in the hard-hit Lombardy region - has recorded more than  virus-related deaths since the start of the outbreak.The crematorium of Bergamo, working at full capacity,  hours a day, can cremate  dead, said a spokesperson for the local authority.It is clear that it could not stand up to the numbers of the past few days.The dead are now being taken to crematoria in Modena, Acqui Terme, Domodossola, Parma and Piacenza.Once the bodies have been cremated, the ashes will be brought back to Bergamo.The Sun Online has already told how morgues  are working round-the-clock in the stricken city.Brother Marco Bergamelli, a priest at All Saints church in Bergamo, told how the church could not cope with the demand.Unfortunately, we dont know where to put them , Bergamelli said. It takes time and the dead are many.Crematoriums are said to be working  hours a day but just cannot keep up.Its asyou were asking what to doan atomic bomb explodes, Dr Antonio Pesenti, the head of Lombardys intensive crisis care unit, told the Washington Post.You declare defeat. Well try to salvage whats salvageable.The news comes as Italy has seen coronavirus deaths surge by , the highest daily increase yet recorded since the disease took hold of the country.Doctors there have warned the country is facing a “catastrophic” situation as the virus spirals out of control with the number of deaths hitting ,.Wednesday also saw a record high in the number of infections with more than , new cases, bringing the total to ,.More than , medical workers have now been infected in Italy - more than eight per cent of the countrys total cases.The rapid increase in deaths comes despite Italy imposing a draconian lockdown, a situation the UK is moving towards with the closure of schools.Italy is set to overtake China, where the COVID- pandemic first emerged late last year and which has seen , deaths, most in the hard-hit central province of Hubei.Italy has an older population than Chinas, but only has  million people to Chinas . billion people.Medical experts say the new virus is killing people over  at a much higher rate than other age groups.Italy’s doctors have described patients who would normally be in intensive care having to be left on wards without the equipment or staff to properly treat them.Among the hospitals struggling to cope is the -bed Papa Giovanni XXIII Hospital in the affluent city of Bergamo.It is in the region of Lombardy in the north, which was the first region in the country to be locked down as the crisis first got underway.Almost half the hospitals beds are currently occupied by coronavirus patients, and three of its four most senior staff are currently at home ill.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Speaking to the Wall Street Journal, an intensive care specialist Mirco Nacoti at the hospital, said: Until three weeks ago, we did everything for every patient.Now we have to choose which patients to put in intensive care. This is catastrophic.To add to the misery, it has now emerged one of first people struck down by coronavirus has tested positive again days after being given the all-clear by medics.The unnamed -year-old - who is Turins so-called patient number one - has been closely monitored by doctors for weeks.The patient was just about to be sent home after testing negative for the killer infection, say reports.However, a control test then found he was still positive-  meaning he will have to remain in hospital lockdown.Among those to have died in the past  hours was a patient with no underlying health conditions.The patient was a GP from the region of Lombardy, the first part of the country to be locked down amid the crisis.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus panic buyers queue tesco
story: CORONAVIRUS panic-buyers were today queuing down the aisles at am to fill their trolleys – despite stores issuing strict rules and limiting customers to buy just three of each item.Pictures from around the country show thousands of desperate customers lining up to pay for their goods as more heartbreaking images emerged showing elderly people staring at empty shelves.Hundreds of people were seen queuing to get into supermarkets in Newcastle, Nottingham and New Malden, South West London, before they opened this morning.One poignant image showed an elderly woman staring at empty shelves in her local Tesco store in Kent after it was announced , troops are ready to join the fight against coronavirus.The death toll has now reached  in the UK with confirmed cases up to ,.And Brits are now rushing to stores to buy food items, toilet roll and soap – the day after a heartbreaking picture of an elderly man staring at empty shelves shamed panic buyers.Sheela, who filmed the clip in Romford, said: “They are limiting the number of people in the store because everyone cant get through the tills.“There is now a queue to enter the store. I can see they have quite a lot of food and frozen meats.”Earlier this week, major supermarkets announced they have limited customers to purchasing just three of each item as coronavirus panic buying title: london homes no water coronavirus pipe
story: THOUSANDS of Londoners were left without water this morning amid the coronavirus lockdown.A pipe burst in south London causing chaos for homes and businesses trying to regularly wash their hands to keep safe from the virus.Thames Water said staff were urgently fixing the problem to get supplies back to normal for about , people.A statement on their website confirmed there is low pressure or no water in several South West and West London postcodes today.It added: Our specialist engineers are already on their way to investigate the problem, and they will be doing everything they can to get things up and running as quickly as possible.We’re really sorrythis has disrupted your day. We know this has happened at an especially dficult time and we understand the concerns you may have.By midday many relieved people reported they had water once more.It comes after Prime Minister Boris Johnson asked Brits to stay in and work at home where possible as the crisis worsens.Today , cases were reported in the UK, with  deaths.One frantic person tweeted: Several thousand homes in West London including mine have NO running water and NO electricity as of this morning. This is just a total breakdown of trust of whoever is in charge.And another said: London hit by major water shortage  power cut amid coronavirus pandemic!People aren’t able to wash their hands in South West  West London.Around , homes are without water this morning after a pipe burst in south London. title: eu boss michel barnier reveals he has coronavirus
story: The blocs chief Brexit negotiator confirmed the news on Twitter this morning.He wrote online: I would like to inform you that I have tested positive #COVID . Im fine, morale is good. I naturally follow all the instructions, just like my team.He said he was being strictly confined to his home and was as well as can be in a video message.And he expressed his soldairty with others fighting the illness around the world.Mr Barnier added: In this grave crisis we all have a personal response, solidarity, unity and benevolence, and will all of this we can exit this crisis stronger than before.Former colleague Guy Verhofstadt and several others took to social media to wish him a speedy recovery.The news will throw Britains aims to get a trade deal with the bloc by the end of the year into chaos.Boris has repeatedly insisted he wont delay our final exit from the EU, which is set for the end of December.He told a press conference last night: It’s not a subject that’s being regularly discussed, I can tell you, in Downing Street at the moment.And we’re getting on with it. There’s legislation in place that I have no intention of changing.”However, talks which were meant to take place this week in London have already been ditched over the ongoing coronavirus crisis.No are in discussions about trying to set them up via videolink.Meanwhile:The Commission said today: For the moment main focus of work is on analysing texts on both sides. Negotiations will be carried forward.We believe there are ways to ensure even in current circumstances negotiations can continue to take place. In any case there will very regular contacts.Politicians and experts said the transition period might now have to be extended over the ongoing Covid- chaos.The EU has already said it would consider an extension of the transition periodneeded, because they think its not yet enough time to seal a deal anyway.But the exit is currently enshrined in law of pm on New Years Eve .Boris would have to change the law to stop that from going ahead.Lib Dem Ed Davey said: The prime minister has got his head in the sand.“His refusal to guarantee an extension to the Brexit talks is reckless and a dangerous example of putting politics above the needs of the country during the coronavirus crisis.Simon Usherwood, Professor of Politics at the University of Surrey, said: Most obviously, the smashing of the already-tight timetable for moving into a new UK-EU relationship means that there will have to be a decision about extending the current transition period.The government will have to judge whether the UK could stand failing to secure a deal by January  when it’s still working through the massive aftershocks of coronavirus, both economic and political.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tummy ache sign coronavirus scientists discover
story: WITH coronavirus quickly spreading, people are being urged to look out for the key signs of the deadly illness.The NHS warns the main symptoms of Covid- are a new, continuous cough, a high temperature - meaning you feel hot to touch on your chest or back - and shortness of breath.However, US scientists have now claimed that those with Covid- might also experience a tummy ache before developing these flu-like symptoms.A new study, published in the American Journal of Gastroenterology, suggests people might experience digestive issues, such as diarrhoea, when they are infected with coronavirus.Researchers analysed data from  patients with Covid- in China’s Hubei province and they discovered that . per cent of these patients arrived at the hospital with digestive symptoms such as diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain.Following this, the researchers stated that, for some people, digestive symptoms may present itself first before the respiratory symptoms of Covid-.On top of this, the people included in the study also had a more severe case of illness.Brennan M.R. Spiegel, co-editor-in-chief of the American Journal of Gastroenterology, said: In this study, Covid- patients with digestive symptoms have a worse clinical outcome and higher risk of mortality compared to those without digestive symptoms, emphasising the importance of including symptoms like diarrhoea to suspect Covid- early in the disease course before respiratory symptoms develop.Despite this revelation, people should still be vigilant in looking out for the primary symptoms of coronavirus including a dry cough and high temperature - as Covid- primarily attacks the lungs and respiratory system.Some patients may also have aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose or a sore throat - but these are usually mild and begin gradually.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Developing these symptoms does not necessarily mean you have the illness and they are similar to other illnesses, such as the common cold or flu.Some people will not develop all of these symptoms -  and some might not even show symptoms at all, experts say.Sir Patrick Vallance, the UKs chief scientic adviser, said: It looks quite likely that there is some degree of asymptomatic transmission.There’s definitely quite a lot of transmission very early in the disease when there are very mild symptoms.Around one out of every six who gets Covid- become seriously ill and develops dficulty breathing, according to the World Health Organisation .Older people, and those with underlying medical problems like high blood pressure, heart problems or diabetes, are at most risk developing serious illness.This can include pneumonia and swelling in the lungs, which can make it hard for the lungs to pass oxygen into the bloodstream - leading to organ failure and death.Severe pneumonia can kill people by causing them to drown in the fluid flooding their lungs.People with fever, cough and dficulty breathing should seek medical attention, the WHO says.The virus is believed to be transmitted between people through droplets spread from coughing and touching or shaking hands.While sneezing is not a symptom of the new coronavirus, its also thought to be a way that droplets can be spread.Tap to see where COVID- is near youSymptoms are thought to appear between two and  days.New research has found that the average incubation period of Covid- is . days.A study by the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health in the US found that almost allof those who develop symptoms appeared to do so within . days of infection.Experts say there is little evidence to suggest that people can spread the virus without showing symptoms.Currently, there is no vaccine to protect people against the virus.Antibiotics do not help, as they do not work against viruses - only bacteria.The NHS says that treatment aims to relieve the symptoms while your body fights the illness.Those who are infected will need to stay in isolation away from other people until they have recovered.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: scrapping bbc licence fee coronavirus august
story: Plans to charge the annual £. fee from June  were already put on hold until August but now the crisis could delay this even further.It comes amid fears that the elderly will be told to stay in their homes for up to four months to try and stop them from getting coronavirus.BBC Director General Tony Hall said this morning: The board met on Sunday to take that decision, to put the implementation off until August, and the phrase is under review.I think on all of this ... we must just keep doing what we think is right each day and keep everything under review.Ministers had said that plans were to try and shield older and more vulnerable from the deadly bug.Age UK earlier warned the elderly will be “even more reliant” on their TV and radio for entertainment  during this “unprecedented situation” when they will be consigned to their homes, with family and friends unable to visit.And they will also need to stay informed about developments in the coronavirus outbreak, with many elderly people not online like the rest of the country.The BBC revealed plans last year to ditch the free licence for over s as part of cost cutting measures.Meanwhile:The BBC and Department for Culture, Media and Sport earlier said: During this time we do not want anyone to be worried about any potential change.The BBC’s priority over the coming period will be to do everything we can to serve the nation at this uniquely challenging time.And Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden welcomed the pause on the plans.He added: It is right that the BBC have recognised the exceptional circumstances posed by the Coronavirus outbreak and the need for the whole country to pull together in the national effort.On demand TV – like catch-up TV and on demand previews – which are available through services like ITV Player , All , My , BT Vision BT TV , Virgin Media , Sky Go , Now TV, Apple TV, Chromecast , Roku and Amazon Fire TVOn demand movies - from services like Sky, Virgin Media, BT Vision, Netflix and Amazon Instant VideoRecorded films and programmes- either via DVD or Blu-ray, or downloaded from the internetYouTube - On demand video clips through services like YouTubeMinisters are consulting on whether to scrap the licence fee altogether, it was revealed earlier this year.Ex-Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan said the BBC needed to up its game to keep up with modern Britain.After , the fee could be long gone.And they are looking at plans to decriminalise not paying the fee, too.

title: young people severe coronavirus stop pubs
story: YOUNG people have been warned to take coronavirus seriously and STOP going to the pub - or risk severe illness.The governments top advisers have today said that to fight Covid- everyone needs to follow social distancing measures.It comes after the Prime Minister told the public to avoid mass gatherings, including steering clear of pubs, theatres and restaurants.The government is preparing to potentially enforce tougher restrictions in London to keep people inside - which would see social spots like pubs shut down.Advising young people not to be complacent, Boris Johnsons chief medical adviser, Professor Chris Whitty, said that young people are getting severe forms of the illness.He told a press conference today: There are some young people who have ended up in intensive care, or who have ended up with severe disease around the world. But I think it’s important that we don’t give the impression that every single young person is just going to breeze through this.The great majority will have a mild or moderate disease and will get through this.But there will be some young people who will have severe disease, even though they are otherwise young and healthy - and we have seen cases around the world.We need to be aware that this is not a trivial infection for everybody, eventhey are a young adult.Sir Patrick Vallance, the governments chief scientic adviser, added: Unless everybody looks at the measures introduced by the government on social distancing it doesnt have the effect.So what we absolutely shouldnt encourage is the idea that young people can somehow ignore it because they’re going to be fine.The mixing in pubs and restaurants that we’ve said are really a part of allowing the disease to spread needs to stop.And it needs to stop amongst young people as well as older people.It comes as a report in the US warned younger people make up a large proportion of coronavirus patients.The Centers for Disease Control and Preventionfound of the  patients known to have been hospitalised with the bug,  per cent were younger - aged between  and .Professor Stephen Morse, at Columbia University, warned: I think everyone should be paying attention to this.Its not just going to be the elderly. There will be people age  and up.They do have to be careful eventhey think that theyre young and healthy.The warnings come amid reports in Italy and France of young people being hospitalised and needing intensive care.Butthat many younger people are being hospitalised, that means there are a lot of young people in the community that are walking around with the infection.So far,  people have died after testing positive for coronavirus in the UK and tens of thousands of people are thought to be infected.Experts are desperately trying to develop a vaccine for the new illness, but warn that it could take months.When asked about dferent strains of the virus, Prof Whitty said with a strong caveat of scientic speculation that it was expected to mutate.He said there was a chance that the virus could mutate around the vaccine, but that some mutations could be actually useful.Smaller mutations... help to track family trees of the virus, said Prof Whitty, adding that this would help scientists to understand and tackle the disease.Sir Patrick added that the UK was absolutely world-class in addressing viral mutations.Tap to see where COVID- is near you To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Meanwhile, analysis from Edge Health suggested the NHS will face substantial pressures on critical care beds as the outbreak continues.According to their modelling, there will be a shortfall of , beds in the Midlands at peak Covid- ventilator demand, while the south west has the fewest critical care beds and will need a % increase, or ,, to meet demand.Schools across the UK were preparing to close to all pupils except those of key workers in a bid to halt the diseases spread.Mr Johnson said measures taken so far were helping to slow the spread of the disease, but he did not rule out tougher measures being enforced down the line.The PM also did not rule out stricter controls being imposed on London ahead of the rest of the nation, with fears of a lockdown being imposed like in other nations.Transport for Londonannounced up to  Tube stations would be closed on Thursday and a reduced service would run on the rails from Friday.London Mayor Sadiq Khan warned Londoners they should not be travelling unless they really, really have to, but insisted the network must remain open to aid frontline health workers.Meanwhile, the number of troops in a heightened state of readiness will be doubled to , while Reserves were to be placed on standby to support public services in a new Covid support force.The Ministry of Defence was also planning to put  military personnel into training to drive oxygen tankers around the country to support the NHS.A number of supermarkets are continuing The source said: Our priority is to work up solutions that can be deployed quickly, are effective and reach the right people. Critics say a universal income could take some time to work up, and it would reach everyone by its nature rather than only those with most urgent need.  Mr Johnson said introducing a universal basic income to aid financially hit workers will certainly be considered and agreed to hold talks with supporters of the proposed scheme. It comes after calls from Labour leadership contender and shadow business secretary Rebecca Long-Bailey who said a streamlined cash measure was needed with the pandemic yet to fully sink in for most people.In the meantime, amendments to the current Universal Credit system are also being toyed with by the Treasury, among a range of other measures - while some experts say GDP could plummet by a fth before .  The PM has already vowed to safeguard private renters from eviction due to the virus, with landlords barred from starting the ball rolling on evictions for at least  weeks. On Tuesday, UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced a £bn package to help businesses stave off ruin as the country goes into semi-lockdown with social distancing likely meaning certain sectors could be decimated without proper Government support.This could otherwise lead to swathes of job losses, particularly in London where one in seven people work in the tourism, hospitality and leisure sector. There are also fears that Government loans and aid measures - amounting to a £bn boost - will only paper over the cracks and that grants are needed to ensure proper futures for those companies at risk, while some have called for national insurance to be halted and VAT bills deferred as well. Some, including Adam Marshall, chief executive of the British Chambers of Commerce, have said the level of cash handouts and rates holiday to smaller firms - as part of a £million injection - would be great, but said the money needs to get out quickly. Lib Dem acting leader Sir Ed Davey urged the DWP to suspend all benefit sanctions, assessment and reassessments in light of the coronavirus pandemic. He told Work and Pensions Secretary Therese Coffey: No one should be worried about sanctions for failing to attend an appointment, especially in light of the Government’s latest advice on social distancing, self-isolation and avoiding public transport. According to the Resolution Foundationaposs plan, there would be a new SRP rate modelled on Statutory Maternity Pay. It would retain the link between firms and staff, thus avoiding the need for mass redundancies.Supporting a million workers via a flat-rate scheme of £ per week for an initial six months would cost around £. billion. A more ambitious earnings-linked scheme, in which staff are paid at least two-thirds their typical salarywould cost around £ billion. The think tank also calls for increasing unemployment benefits and Universal Credit to £ per week.

title: damning windrush report finds home
story: NewsDamning Windrush report finds Home Office guilty of institutional ignoranceThe inquiry by Wendy Williams said the scandal was “foreseeable and avoidable” and blamed ministers and officialsShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  MAR NewsThe Home Office was heavily criticised " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Home Office was guilty of “institutional ignorance” and “thoughtlessness” to the Windrush generation, a report found today. The inquiry by Wendy Williams said the scandal was “foreseeable and avoidable” and blamed ministers and officials. Home Secretary Priti Patel said she apologised unreservedly for the “unimaginable suffering” for the hundreds of people affected. The report was ordered in the wake of the  scandal that saw hundreds of people who came to this country from the Caribbean threatened with detention and deportation even though they had a legal right to live in the UK. The Williams report said the Windrush generation of Caribbean migrants and their children had been “poorly served by this country.” “They had every right to be here and should never have been caught in the immigration net. “The many stories of injustice and hardship are heartbreaking, with jobs lost, lives uprooted and untold damage done to so many iniduals and families. “However, despite the scandal taking the Home Offce by surprise my report sets out that what happened to those affected by the Windrush scandal was foreseeable and avoidable,” the report said. Ms Williams said that even when stories started to emerge of how people were being mistreated the Home Office was “too slow to react.” “A range of warning signs from inside and outside the Home Offce were simply not heeded by offcials and ministers,” her report says. It said there was a culture of “disbelief and carelessness” at the department when dealing with the Windrush generation who were “failed when they needed help most.” She added: “While I am unable to make a defnitive fnding of institutional racism within the department, I have serious concerns that these failings demonstrate an institutional ignorance and thoughtlessness towards the issue of race and the history of the Windrush generation within the department, which are consistent with some elements of the defnition of institutional racism.” The report makes  recommendations, including calling on the Home Office to come up with a plan within six months to improve how it deals with immigration issues.It also calls for a full review of the “hostile environment” - the tough new rules on migration implemented by former Home Secretary Theresa May.Other recommendations include the creation of a Migrantsapos Commissioner to champion migrants to the UK and a new training programme for all Home Office staff.  Ms Patel told MPs she would respond to the recommendations in the next few months.She said there was nothing she could do to undo the “suffering and misery inflicted on the Windrush generation.“What I can do is say aposIaposm truly sorryapos. Iaposm sorry peopleaposs trust has been betrayed.”Labour MP David Lammy called for recommendations to be implemented in full and said the report was a “brutal indictment of the Home Office.”He said what happened was not a mistake or an accident but a “systemic” pattern of behaviour “rooted in a toxic culture.” Mrs May told MPs she associated herself with the apology made by the Government. “I gave my apology previously and I do so again today,” she said.

Stores that previously opened  hours, will also now close at pm each evening.  The move follows similar measures by Sainsburyaposs, Aldi, Asda and Morrisons, to ease stockpiling pressure amid the Covid- outbreak. Sainsburyaposs revealed it will only allow customers to buy a maximum of three of any single item, while Morrisons said it is limiting purchases across , lines. Asda also announced it is restricting shoppers to three items on all food and closing its cafés and pizza counters, while temporarily reducing the opening hours of all its -hour stores for re-stocking. Aldi has already introduced limits of four items per shopper across all products.  Tesco boss Mr Lewis wrote to staff on Wednesday: It is fair to say that we find ourselves in uncharted waters. Covid- is bringing a change to the UK and itaposs clear that lots of things are going to have to sht around in order to help us cope.At Tesco, we have been doing everything we can to keep business as usual, but we now have to accept it is not business as usual. In the last two weeks, we have seen signicant and prolonged increases in demand across all of our stores and this is leading to shortages in some products for some customers. It comes as Britainaposs supermarket chains are also launching action to help elderly and vulnerable customers, while ramping up operations to meet surging demand for home deliveries.  Sainsburyaposs became the latest group to offer priority home delivery slots to elderly and vulnerable customers, as well as exclusive shopping hours. Its supermarkets will only open to these two groups for the first hour of trading on Thursday, chief executive Mike Coupe said, but will open for an hour longer so other shoppers do not miss out. Sainsburyaposs Local convenience stores will not offer the service. Supermarkets have seen a huge rise in demand for delivery services, with no slots available until next month for both Tesco and Waitrose in some parts of the south east. The surge came as Transport Secretary Grant Shapps authorised a temporary relaxation, until April , of the driversapos hours rules to help deliver goods to stores across the country. The government has advised the British public to:Avoid pubs, clubs, restaurants and all social gatherings Cease all unnecessary travel Everyone should work from home where possible Mass gatherings and sporting events have been cancelled Avoid “all but essential travel” worldwide If one person in any household has a persistent cough or fever, everyone living there must stay at home for  days Pregnant women, those over , and people with certain health conditions have been asked to stay at home for  weeks Schools, colleges and nurseries to close from Friday - GCSEs and A-levels cancelled A Department for Transport statement said the relaxation applies only to drivers supplying food and essential products to supermarkets. The statement added: This includes the movement of such goods from importers, manufactures and suppliers to distribution centres. It does not apply to drivers undertaking deliveries directly to consumers. Iceland outlets across the country have also introduced reserved time slots to give the vulnerable and the elderly a chance to shop in store. Sainsburyaposs said customers over  and those with a disability will have priority access to online delivery slots from Monday, and the chain is also expanding its click and collect service.

Tabatha Stirling, from Leith in Edinburgh, was unable to find any pasta for her -year-old son Teddy, who has Aspergeraposs and a selective eating condition, due to panic-buyers emptying supermarket shelves. Teddyaposs condition is common in autistic children and means that certain colours, textures and smells can put them off eating, Edinburgh Live reports. Tabatha said she was initially not worried about panic-buyers stockpiling certain long le items but only realised the extent when she tried to go shopping herself:She said: “It really ramped up this week, I took my  year old after school to Sainsbury’s and it was shocking. After just a short while, the online community both on Twitter and Facebook showed support for Tabatha’s request, resulting in her receiving more than  messages and tweets of generous offers.Donors included restaurant chain Prezzo who invited Tabatha to visit their Edinburgh branch for a bag. title: coronavirus nine questions schools closure
story: NewsCoronavirus: Nine questions on schools closure answered with all we know so farEducation Secretary Gavin Williamson said schools will shut at the end of Friday and be shut indefinitely - the Government have not yet put a date on when they may reopenShareCommentsByTristan CorkDan BloomOnline Political EditorDanya Bazaraa:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsSchools in Britain are closing on Friday" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The Government has announced a full shutdown of all schools with the exception of children of key workers as of tomorrow amid the coronavirus pandemic.This announcement came as the Education Secretary said people will be able to go to college and university without having sat GCSE or A-level exams. Gavin Williamson reiterated last nightaposs announcement that no exams will take place this academic year, before the summer term. Askedhe anticipated people still going into higher and further education without undergoing a formal exams process he told Sky: Yes, thataposs right. He added further guidance about how to do this will be published on Friday and talks with school leaders are still ongoing. The Education Secretary said there will have to be an appeals process for any pupil who feels theyaposve been wronged. The Mirror understands it is possible universities could use predicted grades,they resume as normal in September, but this is not confirmed. But what will the schools closure mean for children, parents and families Here is everything we know so far, as reported by Bristol Live.  What schools are involved  The Prime Minister made it clear that all schools would be involved in the shutdown across England, following announcements in Scotland and Wales. Mr Johnson also said that he would be aposexpectingapos childrenaposs nurseries, pre-schools, sixth-forms and colleges to also close their doors.  How long will the shutdown be for  The Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said that schools will shut their gates at the end of Friday and then be shut indefinitely - the Government are careful not to put a time frame or date on when they may reopen. When asked by journalists at the Number  briefing that happened simultaneously, Mr Johnson appeared to rebuff the suggestion, made in Wales and Ireland, that the school closures could be for as long as six months - that Friday would effectively mark the end of the school year, and the summer term after Easter would simply not happen, with schools reopening in September. He said he would hope that schools could reopen before then, but with the coronavirus pandemic rapidly spreading throughout Britain, there is no certainty at all on when they would reopen.  Who will still go to school  The Education Secretary said that schools would remain open for the children of keyworkers, to ensure that people who the country needs to continue to go to work and not worry about childcare, will be able to do so. The Prime Minister said these would be the children of NHS workers, police and emergency services personnel and aposdelivery driversapos who are critical to ensuring the continuing working of the food supply from farm to factory to shops. The Prime Minister said exactly who would be in this list would be revealed this week, before Friday - but there are no firm details as yet, on Wednesday evening.   What about grandparents  There was a specic warning from the Prime Minister that, under no circumstances, children should be now looked after by their grandparents, once they are home from school. That generation of older people are the most vulnerable to coronavirus, and the message from the scientists is that young people and the elderly should be kept apart to avoid older people catching the virus.  What should parents do  One of the key reasons why schools are now being closed is to further ensure that a partial lockdown of society happens. Parents are being asked to look after their children at home, and not leave them with grandparents, and this move is designed to increase the numbers of people who largely withdraw and remain in their homes, to stop the further spread.Most controversially, however, Boris Johnson again held back from making lockdowns and closures of businesses an order - even though all other countries in Europe are pursuing those more severe measures.  What about exams  The Prime Minister confirmed that, given schools will be closed for a considerable time and exams start in May, this yearaposs  GCSEs and A-levels would be scrapped. This does mean that exams will not take place in May and June as planned, but we will make sure that students get the exams they need and deserve, said Mr Johnson. Quite how that happens is unclear, but the most likely explanation will be some kind of grade awarded from coursework already completed, or predictive grades or grades from mock exams.  What about vulnerable children  School children who are classed as vulnerable will be still be allowed to go to school - this includes children who have an EHCP - children with special needs - and children who have a social worker or are in care.  What about Free School Meals  The Prime Minister outlined that they would be rapidly drawing up plans for a voucher scheme for children who are entitled to free school meals - but who will now not be at school to receive it each day - to get that food or support. The details of how exactly this works are yet to be revealed.
